This is affordable and does all you need it to do so long as you aren’t trying to stream at max settings.Great chip and even though I can afford the 8th, 9th I’m sticking with the 7700k because it is very high quality.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W

Great chip, but Intel should have charged an extra $10 and not used crappy thermal compound between the chip and the heat spreader

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W

After seeing the performance of this chip in an ASUS PRIME Z270-A LGA1151 motherboard, I saw it rip through the toughest and slowest apps including backups, imaging, heavy file processing. No regrets. I don't know what your upgrade path strategy is, but this chip will serve you well in years to come depending on how you look at your equipment investments.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsGood solid Intel 7th generation i7 CPU for gamers
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2018

Buyer beware. This CPU only works with Z27 chipset for 7th gen. I tried to put it on X37 board. It did not work. Don't make the same mistake. X37 chipset only supports 8th gen i7. 7th gen i7 supports only up to DDR4 up to 2400MHz.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W

I have this CPU sitting in my Corsair Carbide 400C Compact Mid-Tower Case with an ASUS Z270 M1 Motherboard, Corsair H105 AOI CPU Cooler, 64gb of Crucial Ballistix RAM, ASUS GeForce 1080GTX Turbo GPU, Corsair HX850i PSU, 4 Corsair SP-120 fans, and an ADATA SU800 512gb SSD running Windows 10 Pro 64-bit and all I can say is I couldn't be happier with it's performance.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-7700K Desktop Processor 4 Cores up to 4.5 GHz Unlocked LGA 1151 100/200 Series 91W
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsI am not a hardcore gamer but it does consume ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2017
Reviews: I am not a hardcore gamer but it does consume a lot of my time and I pay close attention to detail. I have this paired up with a GTX 1060 6 GB and it will run almost anything I throw at it on ultra. Some newer stuff and less optimized games, PUBG, will still drop below 60 every now and then. Typically tweaking a few things to a lower setting will resolve this.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsExcellent CPU, though powerful cooling is a must.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2023
Reviews: Originally bought this back in 2016. Been in service in my main workstation ever since then, and it shows no signs of stopping. I've had it paired with a Noctua NH-D14 cooler since Day 1 (the Intel stock cooler literally hasn't come out of the box in the nearly 7 years I've had it) and it's been a workhorse. It still holds its ground quite well, only obsoleted by the fact that nothing newer than an LGA1150-socket motherboard supports it.Powerful cooling is a *MUST* with Haswell, as these CPUs run HOT, especially under heavy AVX/AVX2 loading, as video rendering tends to do, hence the Noctua NH-D14. Regardless of the heatsink that you install on it, you need to ensure that the heatsink gets good, clean air.Overclocking is a bit of a delicate ballet with these CPUs, as well. YMMV, but I had to lock my ring voltage to 1.2 or 1.3V, ring frequency to 4000MHz, memory voltage to 1.35V, and then I set the FSB to 100MHz with a 46x multiplier. All power-saving states off, core voltage @ 1.250 or 1.255V, and it's stable under 100% all-core load in the form of intense AVX2 load by way of rendering x265/HEVC video @ 1080p60.Overall, an excellent chip that holds its ground very well, but has a few specific things to be aware of.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsA superb CPU, but not a good value anymore...newer series are cheaper.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2018
Reviews: For a little intro, I build customs on contract, buy everything up front and have tried just about everything.  This chip is in 7 clients' builds yet today, because every time they ask about upgrading I bring them over and let them sit down in front of the newest and prettiest, be it the venerable 6850K, 5930K, 5820K, 6700K, 6800K, 7700K and now the 8700K (I'm not a fan of the i9's or X's).  Nothing I have is noticeably better all around than this CPU, period.  You can take the specs and wipe with them for all the difference you'll actually see in real life applications.  It's no fun to say that because I WANT to see a difference.  I can clock this thing to 4.7 on water with such a small adjustment in voltage it's crazy, and rise only 5-7 degrees C with a custom loop to idle at 38-40 degrees and run hot right around 50 (a little of it is due to my loops and 20+ years of building), but no other CPU I've used  reacts like that.  I own games.  I've never finished 95%  of them because to this day almost nothing taxes the CPU.  So I test with video editing.  4 cores and 8 threads is enough for any normal human, if you're a pro then you'll want something for an X99 or 2011/2066 board.The only cons are that this is going up in price and Z97 boards are harder to find new.  When I read that the 6700K, 7700K and 8700K are upgrades I just grin.  And why the 6 and 7 series were produced at all is nothing but marketing and little tweaks that aren't noticeable.  I have a Threadripper as well as all the above and more, and when you want to be stunned then see what all those cores are good at and compare THAT to Intel's consumer chips.  AMD's version of the Xeon is NOT great all around but the Intel folks aren't any smarter than the AMD developers, they only have deeper pockets to draw from and a longer history of doing the same thing the same way.  That's why the 4790K stands out...but until the 8700K I think Intel was just punching the clock.  It's a superb CPU that's NOT going down in price AT ALL because it's still so viable that the software has yet to catch up.  If it's used with the right board, with the right RAM and BIOS set the right way I'd still put it up against the 8700K built by 95% of the market that's buying them and getting their comparisons on their cell phones and shouting specs from the rooftops :-)  Next time just ask them how many Ghz to fill a gallon halfway?!!  It get's pretty peaceful. :p

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGreat performance. High heat.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2014
Reviews: This processor will run hotter than the older Core processors. You should also check your BIOS voltages, most OC websites recommend 1.2V for 4.4GHz to see about 6°C tem. drop without loss. This Processor will test 25°C bellow Maximum operating reported by Intel Processor Diagnostic Tool 64-bit, running at 86°C using Corsair Link to verify processor temperature. So I am assuming the maximum specified temperature, before forced shutdown, is at or about 110°C (I am a sensor error of +/-5°C). There are also articles Benchmarking the i7 4790K with all fans set to low and the processor runs at a constant 100°C with only none, or negligible loss. meaning, to burn this processor you would have to do something wrong, or it has to be defective in the first place. It was tested at factory, so defects should be minimal, only thing you have to worry about is shipping competency of the warehouse. Mine was shipped... OK, it works for now... though I can't get used to the high temperatures. I am using a H80i Corsair ... still seeing 80's on stress tests. Gaming, with good GPU, you won't see above 70's with stock cooler, with a 560 Ti I am seeing 77°C running Mass Effect 3, FireFall (72), Tom Clacy's Splinter Cell Black Ops(75°C)... it really depends on how efficiently they made their engines and how dependent they are on the processor, most FPS games are focused on using the monkey-house GPU rather than the brain-trust CPU.The only drawback is the heat. It will provide you with seamless performance across video compiling to HD gaming, and Autodesk/Solid Works project renderings. It can't be slowed down, let alone stopped. Just invest in cooling to improve product life. Lower temp = longer life. Please Do NOT try to build a system with this in the smaller cases, this is a high performance processor, not suited for internet browsing machines. This is not your casual PC user processor, though if you can spare the dough, why not? Also don't be thrifty on the motherboard, it will gimp your performance. I recommend at least 16GB of DDR3 1600 to complement the processing power.For the OC users, I don't see the need, but if you want to go nuts, be my guest. Just remember it runs hot with factory settings. It OC its self to 4.4GHz at about 1.36V.Used: 38 hours continuously, one interruption for 3 hours to install H80i liquid cooler, ran 12 more hours as of review post time.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsFastest i7 for LGA1150 yet
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2015
Reviews: Very fast CPU, I haven't tried any overclocking yet.  Using the stock frequency and with the "most heat" setting of Prime95 stress tester my liquid cooling system is not able to keep up and it overheats.  Using the "balanced" setting of Prime95 it does fine.  This may not bode very well for overclocking, I may need to upgrade my cooling system.  I'm using a Corsair H60 120mm liquid cooler with Tuniq TX-4 ultra high performance thermal compound.  My previous CPU, an i5 4670K, did not come near overheating under the same conditions.  Since this i7 uses hyper threading on 4 cores for a total of 8 threads, along with the higher frequency, increases it's workload greatly.  I'm also not sure how well Prime95 really simulates actual conditions.  Nothing else I've thrown at it in normal usage causes an overheat.  More testing ahead.  The Amazon "Prime only special" price on this was nice too.Update:I updated to a 240mm water cooler and this CPU is now running much cooler even with some mild overclocking but it still cannot handle Prime95's "most heat" setting.  It immediately overheats.  I think that test may not reflect real world conditions.  Nothing else, even with some overclocking, comes near to overheating the CPU.  I don't know if the Prime95 application was written with this type of processor in mind.  So I will continue to test with a bit more overclocking and see what happens.  I won't test any further with that 'most heat' setting of Prime95. Otherwise this CPU has been working great, no problems at all.  With this CPU and an SSD boot drive Windows 10 boots almost instantly.Update:It was suggested that I try an older version of Prime95 to test (see comments) and it does work as it should with the older 26.6 version.  It runs at 68-70 C using the same settings that caused it to overheat with the later version.  Some internet research verifies this to be an issue between at least some of the latest Intel CPUs and the later Prime95 versions.  I had suspected it to be an issue with Prime 95 and apparently it is.  So if you are going to use Prime95 to test this CPU, I at least, recommend you use the earlier version of Prime95 to avoid prematurely making toast out of your CPU.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThis chip is better than boiled noodles.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2014
Reviews: This bad boy dropped to $289.00 during black Friday. I finally couldn't say no to upgrading my old rig (an almost 6 year old AMD Athlon X3 [yeah that's right, triple core!])After graduating college I finally have a job that can afford me to build something a little nicer than a budget rig. So I splurged on this beast of a cpu and paired it with an ASUS Hero VII Z97 motherboard.To be real with you, the last time I built a rig I had a techie friend with me who kind of babied me through it. I didn't even have half the amount of money sunk into that setup as I do this one... so doing it friendless was terrifying.By that I mean my friend wasn't there. I have friends. I swear.I purchased a Cooler Master Hyper Evo 212 to slap on top and make an "Arctic Silver 5" sandwich. Can I just say there is something supremely horrifying about hearing the creek of a $200 motherboard as I tighten the screws on a heat sink over a $300 processor?Luckily, I did not destroy the setup. Turns out they build this stuff to survive the clumsy hands of a novice such as myself.I planned on overclocking this chip (or else why get the k?) but it's so darn fast right now I just don't feel motivated too. I'm enjoying a stock 4ghz hyper threaded quad-core CPU at an idle of 34-35 degrees and a load of about 60-65. Ran Prime95 and the chip would barely blip above 68 degrees.I truly couldn't be happier with this chip. I'm sure I'll eventually get crazy and start overclocking it... but I just can't think of a practical reason to overclock a chip that is so dang fast on it's own.Look, this is an expensive chip. But you get what you pay for with Intel. AMD is great for a budget rig, but I couldn't be happier with this purchase.I might be eating ramen noodles for dinner for the next month (they don't pay elementary school teachers that much) but at least I'll eat ramen while enjoying my computer time that much more.(Btw... this is unrelated. But add a dash of sriracha sauce to your ramen noodles. I was super impressed with the extra dash of flavor.)

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsArguably the best consumer-grade enthusiast CPU currently on the market.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2014
Reviews: Can't recommend the 4790K enough. Coming from a non-biased view, it's amazing. I've owned both high-end AMD CPUs, older gen Intel i7s, and AMD GPUs, so I'm not stuck to one company over another, but the 4790 is the best processor I've had the pleasure of owning. The performance is just amazing. If you do a lot of video editing and want the speed for processor intense activities like rendering, CAD, etc., the power is there. For gaming and CPU intensive games, it has the speed so you're not being throttled and limited like you were with older generations i7s like my old Clarksfield i7-840QM. If a game you're playing is only utilizing a single core, the 1.87 GHz speed of that older i7 really kills you, but these new 4th generation i7s have all you need and then some, even if running off a single core. I have noticed some in the gaming community saying go with the i5-4670k as it's still good in performance, but cheaper and thus lets you spend more elsewhere. However I wouldn't recommend the i5, as spending a bit more up-front to future proof your computer so you save more down the road is always the better option, and the price difference is negligible. When I purchased this CPU on sale, the price difference between what I bought this for and what the lower-end 4670K costs, is less than I would of spent for a tank of gas.As a side note, as this is a K model and unlocked, it's made for overclocking. If you overclock, these overclock very well, but do tend to run a little hot over their previous iterations, so having a good aftermarket heat sink is a must (or watercooling if that's your thing). However, even if you don't overclock, having this model helps to future-proof your PC by allowing you to squeeze added performance out of the processor, and get you that much more use from your computer before you have to shove out more money for new parts. So I'd definitely recommend the K version even if you don't have immediate plans on overclocking.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
Reviews: I was disappointed that I did not receive a retail product. Instead I received an OEM product, packaged only in a small plastic shell.I opened the package and it was clearly not a new product. There were fine scratches on the top surface of the CPU and some discoloration around the edges. This was the second CPU. The first one (from another seller) was returned unopened because there was a large gouge on the top of the CPU. This one is the second one I ordered.It works and all, but I was disappointed that it was advertised as a new product and I did not receive a new product.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsRuns Too Hot!! Need Liquid Cooler!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2015
Reviews: I reluctantly give this product 5 stars, not because there is anything wrong with the product itself, but instead because of the stock heatsink provided. It's horrible, to say the least.Upon booting my PC after installation the fan wound up, into what I can only imagine was the fastest RPM it could pull. During this wind up, it made the most horrible noise, as if a race car was driving through my house. Once it leveled out at roughly 37c, the fan lowered its RPM's, but it was still incredibly loud, I could hear it over the YouTube videos about replacement options for said fan.When I tried to run Rainbow Six: Siege, the CPU heated up to 105c, and averaged 100c. This was without any overclocking, 16gb RAM, and an R9 390x, plus 2 extra fans in my case.I realized that for any CPU usage, a air cooler just wouldn't do for this CPU. I immediately bought a Corsair Hydro H100i GTX. Upon installation/boot, I didn't hear a whisper of a noise. The CPU idles at around 27c, and running Rainbow Six: Siege/Assassin's Creed: Syndicate/GTA V/Fallout 4 (All on ultra settings) - the CPU never exceeded 60c, and idles around 55c for said games.So the product is incredible, it is what's on the box. The downside is, please do your research for a proper cooling solution that will fit your case. There is no way that the stock cooler will work in any condition at all, and it's literally pointless for them to include it.I debated on leaving 4 stars, because I feel that the product should be marketed in a way to let people know upfront that they will have to invest in a decent cooler (more expenses down the line) to get the product to function as intended. But, I gave it 5 stars because it's just that good of a CPU.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsI Have the Chosen One!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2014
Reviews: Here's my build to add context to the review:CPU: i7-4790KCooler: Corsair H100i (with Noctua fans)Mobo: Asus Maximus VI Gene (mATX)RAM: 8GB G.Skill Ripjaws X (2133MHz)SSD: Intel 730 Series 240GBHDD: Two (2) 3TB Seagate Barracudas in RAID1PSU: Corsair CS550M (80+ gold)Video Card: GTX 750Ti EVGA Superclocked edition(all other parts are irrelevant)My experience with this chip has been nothing but fantastic from the beginning. I have been stress testing my chip for a few days at varying frequencies, and my results were almost unbelievable. I was able to achieve 5.1GHz with my voltage set on auto. I used both P95 and AIDA64 in my testing, both of which my CPU passed with flying colors after a 4 hour "burn in." However, I was not able to make it to 5.2GHz since my PC blue screened after 5 minutes of Prime95.All of this is extremely surprising since I've seen numerous reviews raving that this chip is a bad overclocker. So I've narrowed my possibilities down to three reasons. One, The reviewers who had overheating issues had a bad cooling system; two, they're very bad at using the BIOS; three, I must have the most golden 4790K to hit the shelves. Whichever is the case, I feel I have a great CPU and one that overclocks like a boss. If you don't believe me, I have the CPUID screenshot on my desktop for bragging rights.If you're looking for a great Haswell refresh chip, look no further. This is a phenomenal processor. Or maybe I'm just excited to be upgrading from an AMD Phenom build that I've had since 2008.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsWow what a great purchase
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2023
Reviews: This CPU has been incredible over the years, and it is still going strong. Pretty much any game I play to this day I can maintain over 60FPS. I can stream while gaming and performance is fine as well and that's without even overclocking.  I do sometimes fell this CPU is reaching its end days especially because of Microsoft dropping support for windows 10 and this platform does not meet the requirements for windows 11. But nonetheless it has served me well and I plan to keep using it for another year or so.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 1.0 out of 5 starsOverheats, reaches TJ Max
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2015
Reviews: Overheats severely at stock clock/voltage. I've never overclocked. It hits the thermal shutdown temp within seconds of any CPU stress test and powers off the PC. Went through 3 PSUs and 2 motherboards, reseated Noctua HS/F countless times. I also swapped memory four times, removed the video card, and did everything possible to try to diagnose and fix this.  I didn't even consider the CPU being bad a possibility, but I've now narrowed it down. There's a huge thread about this issue on the Intel support forums and Anandtech documented a manufacturing defect in their official review involving the adhesive pushing the heatspreader away from the die. This defect was present in Ivy Bridge as well and is due to Intel using adhesive instead of solder like on Sandy Bridge.This is the first computer that I didn't obsessively research every part for, guess that'll teach me.The system is quite stable and doesn't go above 70C except for stress tests or AVX workloads which explains why this issue isn't very well known.Intel support thread: https://communities.intel.com/thread/54032?start=0&tstart=0Anandtech review mentioning the defect: http://www.anandtech.com/show/8227/devils-canyon-review-intel-core-i7-4790k-and-i5-4690kedit: I just tried a beta BIOS for my motherboard that was released a week ago and the problem is not as bad, but still extremely problematic. AVX stress test puts all cores at 96C+ within the first few seconds.  Still going ahead with the CPU RMA and hoping I get a better one this time. There are two elements to the problem:1. CPU runs hot due to heat spreader/die gap and crappy thermal compound in between heat spreader+die.2. Many motherboards are giving "too much power" but in reality Intel recommends turning down power levels to where the chip will sometimes not reach full speed during Turboboost, or for a reduced time.  Unacceptable.  This also makes overclocking all but impossible despite the product in question being a marked up K SKU.here's the guide from an Intel employee on the forums:https://communities.intel.com/docs/DOC-23517He even warns against using XMP memory profiles to avoid overheating the CPU(at stock clocks/voltage??).  What a joke.  I appreciate his effort but Intel as a company needs to take some ownership here.  Sadly they likely never will, thanks to zero competition from AMD in the high-end CPU market and the processor working well enough for many people.I have a friend who works IT for a bank and he has this exact same issue but his issue played out in a very different but I suspect a more common way:He never tested the machine to see if it was stable and immediately overclocked with the assumption that a 212+ should be good enough cooling.  It wasn't stable but he chalked this up to the overclock.  It still crashes every week or so and sometimes during games but he's doing nothing to fix it.  I actually put all his motherboard settings back to default and did an AVX stress test.  It triggered the test's overheat alarm at 85C and failed the test within seconds, almost as bad as mine.  He has still done nothing to fix it and the computer is unstable to this day, months later.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSweet processor! Definitely overkill for a basic home user
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2015
Reviews: I got the 4790K for my new build, replacing a 4.5 year old i5-2500K.  This is a pretty amazing processor; most likely overkill for a lot of users, but perfect for people who want the best.  For me, in day to day tasks, I can't really tell a huge difference between my old i5 and this. They're both rocket-fast paired with a SSD.  The difference shows, however, in a gaming environment. The only game I use is Flight Simulator X, which is a CPU-intensive title as compared to other games that rely more on GPU.  For Flight Sim, you get the fastest CPU you can afford if you want the best performance, and you can even skimp a bit on your video card. Although I set a fixed frame rate in Flight Sim, with it at unlimited I get in the 80s at ultra high (tweaked) settings, compared to the 60s with the i5.  Mind you this is with a less powerful video card - a GT740 SC 4GB DDR5 as opposed to a GTX650Ti.  The comparison isn't apples to apples, and would likely be a bit higher with the same card.  Closing words - if you are a gamer, and you want fast, get this. If you do other things that demand huge processing power, get this. If you're a home office user, you're overspending if you get this. Get a Core i5 or even a Core i3 and you'll still be zipping along, but for a lot less cash.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsGreat CPU, Great Performance, Amazing Upgrade!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2014
Reviews: A few months ago I was thinking about upgrading from an AMD A10-6800k to an Intel Core i7-4770k. I wanted to wait a few more months just to see if anything new would come out and I'm glad I waited! Purchased the 4790k along with an ASUS Z97I-PLUS Motherboard and an Intel 180GB 530 Series M.2 Form Factor  because why not.Before I upgraded my build I ran a set of 3D Mark benchmarks and here is the list of components I used and the numbers I got after running the Benchmarks.CPU: AMD A10-6800KMotherboard: MSI FM2-A75IA-E53 Mini ITX FM2GPU: Gigabyte Radeon R9 290X 4GB WindforceRAM: 16GB (2x 8GB) AMD Radeon Gamer SeriesPSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 750WCPU Cooler: Cooler Master Seidon 120XL Liquid CPU CoolerSSD: OCZ Agility 3 120GBCase: Cooler Master Elite 130Cloud Gate -  11074Sky Diver  - 16252Fire Strike - 6692Ice Storm -  70872And here are the numbers after I upgraded the CPU to the Intel Core i7-4790K, Motherboard to the ASUS Z97I-PLUS, and added the M.2 SSD, All of the other components are the same.Cloud Gate -  28209Sky Diver - 28163Fire Strike - 10133Ice Storm -  159277I am very happy that I made the decision to get the 4790k to replace my A10 because now paired with my R9 290x I can play Battlefield 4 at over 100FPS at 1920x1080 with the default settings making me play on Ultra everything. If you are wanting to upgrade to a nice top of the line CPU and have the cash to spare, I recommend this 100%!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsPentium G3258 +  utilities + no advantages in gaming
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2015
Reviews: Unless you will be rendering videos very actively, the "i7" name is there just so you feel good about yourself, for 5 times the price of a Pentium G3258. I have achieved exactly the same FPS in games like Crysis, Dota, LoL, Skyrim, Borderlands 2, the Forest with an EVGA GTX 970 FTW edition. G3258 does not bottleneck games or cause stuttering as long as you stick around the 1440p and below. I have received the same scores for Unigine Heaven benchmark at ultra settings 1080p too.Also it gets very hot for even with the best air cooling. So now you have to add even more money to throw in a solid liquid cooling solution, which will be about twice as much as a G3258 itself.I spoke of this CPU negatively, but the specific CPU I've had run up to 5.0 ghz stably, just too hot. So this thing is still a beast. Fortunately, the extra performance is useless for anyone who wants to game. Please do yourself a favor and get an okay air fan and a Pentium G3258. Not even an i5 is worth it unless you certainly have to play the very few games that are out there that just require at least quad cores.If you need to upgrade in a year or two, you only have to give up a 50-60 dollar piece, because g3258 is that cheap.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsBuy this instead of the 4790 non-K. You won't be disappointed.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2016
Reviews: At the time of this writing there are 1,030 other reviews, many of them quite detailed, so I'll keep it brief. If you are incrementally upgrading your PC, this is the best deal going, period. Previously I was running an i5 2500k. In order to upgrade I had to purchase a new motherboard, owing to the 1150 vs 1151 cpu slot. But I was able to re-purpose my  (expensive) existing 16GB of RAM. Moving up to the next level of processor would have required replacing all of my DDR3 RAM with DDR4. And the MoBo's are more expensive. I figure it would have cost me an additional $400-$500 to realize maybe 10-15% faster performance. No brainer for me.I paired it with an ASUS MoBo, this one...ASUS ATX DDR3 2600 LGA 1150 Motherboards Z97-A/USB 3.1. This allowed me to easily leverage the overclocking potential of the chip. Using the auto OC function of the BIOS, I have been able to achieve Passmark scores in the 12000 range, basically the same as the $100 more expensive  i7-3930K (and don't forget the added costs).All in all I'm super happy with this CPU. Definitely spend the extra couple of bucks for this rather than the non-K version. It's well worth your $$$, and even if you know nothing about OC'ing, there are plenty of MoBo's that will do it for you. It's free performance.Earns my official seal of approval.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsA nice upgrade from my old i5. Great for streaming!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2020
Reviews: I've been rocking an old i5 4670k for the past several years. It has served me well for most of that time, but only having 4 cores finally caught up to me when trying to stream games like Sea of Thieves. The CPU could handle the game well enough on its own, but trying to run SoT, OBS, Discord, and FaceRig all at once? Nope, the poor thing was maxed out at 100% utilization and both my game and stream were dropping frames left and right even when using NVENC on my GPU to encode the stream video.So I bought this i7, overclocked it to 4.5GHz like my old CPU, and next time I streamed I had no trouble at all keeping 60FPS even during intense ship battles and large skeleton fights. Though the 4790k still only has 4 physical cores like the i5, the 8 virtual cores provided via hyperthreading made all the difference for juggling the intense workload incurred by streaming and keeping everything running smoothly. I highly recommend this chip if you're looking to breathe some new life into an aging system.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 stars** VERY ** SATISIFIED,  It Rocks. Spend the money, you wont regret it.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2015
Reviews: My downstairs PC was a very old 2.6Ghz 4GB Core2 Duo circa 2008 that I upgraded piecemeal at times (Win7, more drives, etc).  I realized it's performance was holding me back and I had done the frugal "get your value out of an older device" thing long enough.  I looked at all the current options, including Skylake and X99 40 lane motherboard / chip combos.  I finally settled on this, MSI extreme 7, Samsung EVO 850 Pro SSD, 16gig Gskill RAM and Noctua CPU fanNoctua Premium Quality Quiet CPU Cooler for Intel LGA 2011,1156,1155,1150 and AMD AM2/AM2+/AM3/3+,FM1/2 Sockets NH-U9S.  Boy am I glad I did!  It's just NIGHT and DAY faster than my old system.  Nothing crashes anymore, I have simply thrown a battleship's worth of resources at the problem and hey IT WORKS.  Surfing, telecommuting no longer has any lag.  The thing resumes from sleep in less than 2 seconds.P.S.  it's running just fine with an older Seasonic 550 watt power supply.  I am using a modest, older AMD video card (6670)  as gaming is not my focus.  My CPU temperature hovers at 50 degrees Celsius (122 degrees Fahrenheit) when just surfing but multiple windows open.  Surfing performance would probably get even better with a GTX 950 Strix videocard which I may purchase in near future.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2014
Reviews: I recently purchased this CPU because I was having some video issues on my AMD FX-8350 build. I would get this micro stutter when panning left or right in any of the latest release games or games that require a mid to high range video card to run (Assassin's Creed: Black Flag, Far Cry 3, Metro 2033 etc.) I know my video could handle it as I have a EVGA GTX 780 Ti Super Clocked and I know that beast eats all the latest graphics like they aren't even there so I was a bit concerned why I was getting this stutter. I changed out so many parts it was ridiculous. I finally had enough and changed to this CPU (I used the EVGA Z97 FTW board) and right away that stutter just left as soon as it arrived. Now I'm not saying that AMD is bad by any means, look what's in the next gen consoles, but I sure was tired of fighting with the issue I had and Intel delivered the performance I was hoping for. This was my first Intel build and I have to say I'm a huge fan now. I know its a bit more expensive but it certainly was worth the extra money for it. My EVGA board didn't even need a BIOS update to use this CPU either so I'll be sure to write a good review on that board as its awesome and works just like it should.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGood, but not mind blowing.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2014
Reviews: Its like what others have said in the comments below. The i7-4790K a.k.a Devil Canyon processor is just a factory overclocked version of the i7 4770K a.k.a  Haswell processor. Most will probably be able to achieve a 4.5 Mhz overclock stable and a few others might be able to achieve just a little bit more then that. Far from that 5.0 Mhz on air claim Intel was bragging about prior to release day.Prior to purchasing this processor I owned the Haswell i5 4570 and honestly I have not seen much of a difference in performance between my old Haswell i5 and my new Devil Canyon i7. Game wise, CPU intensive games like Planet Side 2, Day Z, Crysis 3, etc runs just about the same on both processors. Many people have said that the big differences over the i5 lies in applications like video editing, etc. so that is something to consider when deciding. That said, if you already have the previous generation Haswell processor i5 or i7 then the new Devil Canyon processor is not worth the upgrade. If your doing a new build or if you have a processor over a couple of generations old then by all means I am giving the i7-4790K two thumbs up!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 stars... add to what already has been written about this wonderful CPU, but I can only echo the comments ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2015
Reviews: Not much here to be able to add to what already has been written about this wonderful CPU, but I can only echo the comments of others. This CPU is a real powerhouse both in speed and in processing capability. As this CPU runs pretty hot when fully loaded, anyone who uses this CPU to it's full capability will simply need to get another cooling solution beyond what is supplied in the Intel box, or you will experience thermal throttling due to the high temperatures generated. While this CPU can be easily overclocked by a Z97 Motherboard, it really does not have a lot of headroom for extreme overclocking. The current speed of 4.0 to 4.4 GHz is very fast as is. A really significant overclock to 4.8 GHz or better will require a serious investment in custom water cooling, or you have a very rare CPU. As for me, the CPU is fantastic at 4.4 GHz, and not sure I have a need to get any more speed out of it. I am using an old Enzotech Extreme CPU air cooler, testing with AIDA 64 Extreme to stress the CPU, and I am getting about 68" C average temperature out of the CPU at full load, at 1.18 Volts Core. Ummmm.....maybe I will tweak it up a bit. Happy Computing...!!!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2014
Reviews: Pros: Super fast in both multi-threaded and single-threaded tasks. Idles extremely cool. Strangely cool in fact, but in a good way.Cons: Not quite the OC'er Intel wanted us to think it was. But has 4.0 stock & 4.4GHz boost, so that's ok. Runs warm when OC'ed.I have to say that overall I am extremely pleased with my i7 4790k purchase and it's performance. It is so incredibly fast, and is actually just a hair shy of a $500 i7 3930k in most tasks which says a lot. That really is a big deal for a $300 proc.The 4790k idles strangely cool, in the low 20's (C) with my Corsair H80i, and is about 8-10C cooler than an i7 4770k at idle all things being equal. And it stays around 45-48C under work load such as gaming, etc. It is a real beast of a processor.However, overclocking is not as great as we thought it would be. I think Intel's early claims of a new improved TIM and voltage regulation was an exaggeration, and it still doesn't come close to Sandy Bridge's fluxless solder IHS. It may be better than the Haswell version 1.0, I'll give you that - but it's still not "that great." I forsee some serious delidding going on over the next few months on DC and much-much testing.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThe best value you could possibly hope for
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2016
Reviews: I love this thing. I upgraded from an AMD FX-8350 in the summer of 2015. The frame jump was so high that I didn't even realize that I hadn't enable the SLI for the second GTX 970 that I bought along with it. When it sits almost idle, doing small things, it floats around 4.0-4.1GHz. BUT, when you put it under stress(like playing any game or benchmarking it), it jumps up to a stable 4.3GHz. I even saw it sit at 4.4GHz on one benchmark. And the included cooler did a good job of keeping the temp stable when I ran three benchmarks in a row on the 3DMark software too. The stock cooler is actually extremely quiet, also. I love this processor and recommend that you just eat the upfront cost. For the performance it gives, it's entirely worth the money. Combine this with a GTX 970 and you can just about max out Crysis 3 and Fallout 4 at 1080p. Just about. I am very satisfied with my purchase and I don't even plan on upgrading to the 6th gen 6700K whatsoever. I'll just put in another GPU. The performance difference is extremely minimal, and with the cost of the LGA1151 and DDR4 stuff, this is the better value.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsNumber crunching at 100% Turbo boost load
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2015
Reviews: I am successfully running the i7-4790K 24/7 at 100% load on all 4 cores in Turbo Boost (4.4 GHz) while number crunching for the World Community Grid (WCG).  The Intel heat sink and fan are inadequate with core temperatures hitting 100 deg C immediately under full load.  Wattage was successfully reduced by lowering CPU Vcore to 1.150 Volts and  VRIN to 1.710 Volts.  The BIOS of my Gigabyte Z97X-UD3H-BK motherboard allowed setting these voltages lower which was the first step taken to reduce CPU Core temperatures.Chosen to replace the i7-4790K stock heat sink is a Cooler Master Geminll S524 Version 2 CPU Air Cooler with 120 mm Silencio FP fan (RR-G5V2-20PK-R1).  With it, typical core temperatures dropped to 70 – 72 degrees centigrade with maximum variation 67 – 74 deg C under continuous full Turbo Boost load.The software application generating the load is the BOINC client running on Ubuntu Linux 14.04 LS.  Ubuntu installed from CD as easily in my rig as MS Windows  The BOINC client and BOINC manager are best installed using the Linux Synaptic tool.  WCG BOINC preferences allow up to 100% of CPU capacity to be used by the Grid project(s).  Performance measurement and temperature use the i7z tool.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSo fast! Oh so very fast!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2015
Reviews: Oh my god, so fastOverclocked it up to a super stable 4.9GHz, and it just cruises through everything. Combined with a fast SSD and enough RAM, this CPU just cuts through tasks like they are half as intense as they really are. The part about a fast ssd and enough ram is important though, because this CPU likely is never the limiting factor in any process or game, it destroys its part of most tasks. Paired with a 970 it crushes every game I play at 1080p, probably would go for a 980 or 980ti to maintain 60+ framerates at 1440p or above.This is pretty much the pinnacle of performance as far as 4 core processors go, for now, doesn't seem like Skylake 6000 series processors are too much faster.I could have easily gone for an i5-4690K instead, but my laptop had an i7 and gosh darn it, my badass PC would have hyperthreading as well. Besides, as time goes on, more and more applications will take advantage of the performance boost that hyperthreading offers, and since I intend to use this CPU for probably at the very least 3 years (5 more likely), having that extra capability is worth it to me.So fast! O.O

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGood but Not Great
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2014
Reviews: I was surprised that it had a small fan for a core i7 processor but i've been using it for some weeks now and it looks like everything's  working ok, also it came with thermal paste on the cpu which is a plus. I currently run Need For Speed Hot Pursuit on it with all settings high and I'm using only my on board graphics card and it plays beautifully no lag no stuttering with game play whatsoever,... It doesn't feel like it's living up to it's name though when i run Flight Simulator X, (if you don't now about Flight Simulator X it's a flight simulator, but it's a really good game that can test your pc limits),... Some areas of the world with a lot of scenery still has low fps but keep in mind i still don't have a graphics card besides the on board one, so maybe that's why! I'm not very technical about computers but in a nutshell I believe it deserves 4 stars because it is far better than anything i've ever had but not as good as i thought it would be! For $300 USD

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2023
Reviews: Was not in an Intel box, fan was new and chip works fine, but had residual thermal paste on chip.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThe stock fan cools fine, even when playing high-end games like Far Cry4 ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2015
Reviews: I don't OC, but this processor can be overclocked reliably to at least 4.4GHz and above.  The stock fan cools fine, even when playing high-end games like Far Cry4 and CoD Ghosts; Advanced Warfare, etc.  It does not go above about 60C, and cools rapidly to about 28-35C @idle.  I bought this i7 because of it's stock speed, and because I won't OC it, and want fast stock equipment that is reliable. Also, it is one of the reasons my Windows Experience Index has climbed to 7.8--even though the processor is the lowest score I have. I am running a 2666MHz FSB and RAM on a Z97 platform with a SSD and a GTX970, and expect it to be very front-running for years to come. I looked long and hard for the right processor, and believe I have found it!  Though it is "only" a quad-core, it doesn't lack any performance I can see in a usage environment.  There will always be higher performance numbers--but This proc. didn't cost a grand either.  Some say it gets hot; not so with stock settings.  Gotta get water cooling or a larger heatsink/fan if you want to play numbers, instead of enjoying it's stock big-block power for gaming and other applications.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsExcellent CPU even in 2017
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2017
Reviews: Even in early 2017 I was still happy with my purchase of a new Haswell generation i7-4790K. In most metrics it is equal to or outperforms its successor the i7-6700K. The 7700K may now have the edge but like the 6700K is lga1151 and would require updating my current motherboard and ram which is much more expense for little perceived benefit. I decided to purchase this new directly from Amazon because many, used on ebay, regularly go for $250+. Without knowing what the previous owner did to the cpu I'd rather pay $50 more for the assurance that I have a new product with Amazon's excellent customer service behind it. I overclocked only a little but have more satisfactory temperatures at stock configuration of 4ghz base, 4.4ghz turbo which is plenty of power. If you are building an all new system go for the i7-7700k as it will be supported on newer motherboards with newer options like USB-C etc. If you already have a lga1150 motherboard and want to move up from an i3 or I5 this will be cheaper than adopting a whole new motherboard platform and you won't be disappointed.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsYou get what you pay for
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2015
Reviews: Intel i7-4790K will always be good from now and for the next three years or more. Is it worth 300 USD? Let me say that price is relevant to cost of aggravations. Suffice it for me to say that no aggravation and long term satisfaction is worth something, so yes, in my opinion the i7-4790K processor is worth the cost, even if you do not plan to overclock it. Why would you buy this over the lesser yet nearly equivalent i5-4690K? If you have the need for multithreaded simultaneous operations, this processor is hands down light years faster than an i5-4690K. If you are surfing the web or playing games with your system then you probably do not need this processor and the i5-4690K is a much better economical option.Why would I buy a K rated processor over a standard version if I do not plan to overclock it? Simply because they are better processors. When processors are tested, they must pass a myriad of tests before they are marked and shipped. Every processor is guaranteed to operate within the window of specifications, so when you buy one that will outperform the window of specifications, it simply tested better overall.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsIf you can afford it, its worth getting over the i5 hands down.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2015
Reviews: HO-LY S***! This thing is fast.I used this cpu for my elite gaming computer build. On paper this thing is supposed to give "up to" 4.1GHz out of the box, mine gave me exactly 4.0GHz. I'm not complaining, but lets be real, if 80-90% of your customers get 4.0GHz or less out of the box, just say that instead of giving me unrealistic expectations.I bought a nice cpu cooler(evo 212) and overclocked this bitch to 4.4GHz. It took me about 5 minutes and it was surprisingly easy to do. The temps are easily managed(28c idle maybe upper 30's when in "full boom") and gaming is a breeze. I can game hard for hours and watch HD vids at the same time and my cpu won't go past 30% capacity. This is easily the best processor I have ever owned.I would suggest one thing to people who are going to buy this. The stock cooler is a cheap piece of s***. If you are willing to spend ~$340 for this thing, its worth investing in a nice cooler. They aren't expensive and they quite noticeably improve performance and temps.I just became an Intel-processor customer for life.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsIntel Core i7-4790K Haswell Quad-Core 4.0GHz
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2014
Reviews: I purchased this as part of a new desktop build using a Z97 chipset AsRock Extreme6 motherboard in a Corsair case. I picked this particular CPU for its combination of features (performance, power efficient, VT-x) over the AMD FX line (comparable features but not nearly as power efficient), Intel i7-5820K (more cores but lower performance per core), and a few other options. I probably would have been alright saving a few dollars and gone for the standard i7-4790 since I haven't really experimented with overclocking the CPU, but I have that option later if I have the time or inclination later. Paired with a Samsung SSD and 32 gbs of Crucial RAM, it tends to fly on most tasks.One note of warning: I started off using the stock Intel CPU cooler that it came with. I did some 1080p media transcoding using Handbrake and it pushed the CPU temperature up to a very scary 90 degrees Celsius. I stopped the job as soon as I saw it, and ordered a (series) of water coolers. With the Corsair H60 idle temperature is now under 25 degrees and maxes out at 56 degrees with a series of video encodes. I would definitely recommend getting a different CPU cooler.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2014
Reviews: This is first i7 I have ever owned. And man its faster than anything I have ever owned. I was choosing between the i5 4690k or this i7 4790k and my uses were for Gaming and Video/Music editing and to be honest I think I would of been disappointed with the i5 cause this i7 can handle so many programs at once its ridiculous at most I run 8 major programs and it does not stutter or slowdown. Also I do wish I got more memory for it cause I only got 2 8gb and I do fill all 8gb with those programs so that's the only thing holding mine back. Also temps for me are pretty dang low I have a h105 water cooler and the temps stay at 27c to 29c at idel and max load 66 to 68c and that's when my room is cold in the morning. When I have my room at 88f it idels at 33c and max load stays the same so I think its really good especially in my situation that I don't have central ac or any form of ac for that matter. Any ways If you choose this CPU you wont regret it and it will last a very long time.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsAmazing performance, worth every penny!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2016
Reviews: It had been quite a while since I built a new desktop rig, and all I can say is.. holy crap, this thing is amazing. I have been an AMD guy all my life, but I loved the performance of my 3rd gen i7 laptop so much, I decided to move to intel for my desktop. This thing clocked in at just over 12,000 on the benchmark after I built it! It runs unbelievably fast and surprisingly cool using the stock air cooler. While writing this review, the temp is sitting at 38C... in other words, under a light load, it runs basically the same temperature as my body! Now, it does quickly get hot under avery heavy  load (80-100 while using Handbrake for x.264 encoding), but all in all, not bad. I will likely get an aftermarket cooler in the future, but I found that if I limit CPU speed in windows to 95%, it seems to do a great job of keeping the temp <85 and doesn't affect the performance much at all. I only do this because >85 really makes me nervous. All in all, I love it!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2023
Reviews: Amazing

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2020
Reviews: What overheating issue...... I've read a lot of reviews about overheating issues with this chip, I've experienced none of them. Now, I would NOT recommend using the heat sink that is supplied with the cpu. Maybe that's the issue many people were having.I have a pretty basic setup that I use for work and education. I'm have an IN-WIN slim formfactor m-ATX chassis, Asus mobo, and a Samsung SSD. I replaced the exhaust fan that came with the chassis for an 80mm Noctua and I'm using the Noctua NH-L9x65, 65mm Premium Low-Profile CPU Cooler. CPU hasn't gone above 89 degrees.I have two of these boxes, one for my VMware lab and the other for my Cisco network lab. Not one issue. I would suggest to those people having heat issues to look for better cooling/chassis options.Asus mobo B85M-G32GB RAMSamsung pro 512GB SSD

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThis processor could be the best upgrade hardware value you can obtain right now!!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2015
Reviews: This is supposed to be about as fast as you can get with the current generation of processors. With the low price that Amazon Prim was offering, I had no excuse not to get the best. I picked it up with a medium grade Gigabyte MB and WOW.  I had pulled my aging first generation i5-760 along with it's gigabyte MB and honestly expected quite a boost in every category between the two. What I didn't expect was just how large a difference it was in real world application.Every aspect of day to day computing was multitudes faster than it had been. Everything  from booting, opening applications, heavy multi-tasking, etc. was so much faster that I often found myself trying to find things to accomplish to fill in down time ... something I can't remember ever having with my old system.It has greatly increased my ability to substantially increase  my intelligence with the added Youtube and Chive time I know have.The one lesson I truly learned with this exerciser was that obtaining the best is not always the most expensive route to take.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2020
Reviews: I started with an i5 cpu 4 core, and this is a visible and noticeable upgrade from that! I can now run nearly all my games at far better qualities than just minimums since upgrading to this and have far better framerates overall. You'll still need to upgrade any Graphics cards if yours is out of date, but for gaming, home, and streaming uses (like netflix or YouTube or even VR), this card works great!Pricey, for sure. And definitely not something for budget setups. But it definitely helps and has a visible difference. Personally, I'd say it's a good deal if it goes under $260, and to not pay anything over $360, but otherwise, it's a great CPU that's a definitive upgrade for any system!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSo much power, OC isn't even necessary!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2015
Reviews: Sooo good.. I couldn't wait to get this CPU in my new rig. Installation on an ASUS Maximus VII Hero couldn't have been easier. I had no issues at all with installation and it's thoroughly enjoying the exceptional cooling it's receiving from it's Corsair Hydro H100i extreme. I haven't been able to get this little guy to pass 40 degrees, even while gaming. I picked this up for my new rig in order to "future proof" the system. I did this with my last rig and it lasted me 8 years, still running games from the last 2 years on max settings. I'm so glad I went with this CPU as it's fulfilling all my needs without even approaching OC. Someday I'm sure some games with be released that will push it to the limit, but for now I can sit back and enjoy the delicious power without having to bat an eyelash at the CPU temps. Will definitely be picking up another one of these when I build my husband's rig next month!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsBest chip for LGA1150 socket
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2018
Reviews: I got this to upgrade from my i5 4690.  I did not want to spend the money to upgrade my motherboard (and then RAM), and this is the highest tier CPU for the LGA 1150 chipset.  The product arrived factory sealed.  It's as easy to install as any Intel CPU.  Even though it is marketed as running at 4.0, it defaults to 4.2 without manual overclocking.  Whether or not that was a default choice by my motherboard to kick it up or not, I can't say.I'm still running the Cooler Master Hyper 212 EVO (air cooling), and the chip hasn't gone over 60 during any of my normal use - gaming and VR.  It touches 62-64 at times during stress testing, which is still well below anything that would be worrisome.  So you can get some mild overclocking on the chip without converting to liquid cooling.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsBrand new in box with fan
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2023
Reviews: Fantastic upgrade to my 9-year old processor.  Not sure why I didn’t upgrade sooner.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2015
Reviews: I will just have to add my voice to the chorus of praises for this CPU: it's fast, it's really, really fast. And I haven't even overclocked it just yet! Cooled by a Cooler Master Hyper 212 Evo it breezes through everything I have so far thrown at it.Addendum February 8.I really needed to add this as it may be relevant for people who use their computers for 3D/CAD modeling (AutoCAD, BIM, SketchUp, 3D MAX). Some mention has been made of the on-board graphics capabilities of this chip. While waiting on my GPU to arrive I went ahead and bumped the speeds of both the CPU (+10%) and the RAM (currently @ 2400 MHz). I was amazed - you could orbit a shaded complex SU model without a single hitch (monitor resolution 1920x1080). I have not mapped materials as I very rarely do that anyway. A modestly complex BIM model refreshes instantly with 3 open viewports. I now think I only need the GPU to watch HD video. Just make sure you get the latest INTEL graphics driver.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsi7 4790K Enthusiast, High Recommendation For All Gamers
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2022
Reviews: I will never leave the i7 4790k until there's another quad-core processor that can beat it at DDR3 with 5-6+ GHz speed. I play games that require strong single-core processing from time to time, upgrading to their latest crap multicore won't do anything for me except for newer games and programming. Intel needs to make the next i7 4790K with higher processing speeds and stick with DDR3.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsPlenty of power, runs relatively cool.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2016
Reviews: I upgraded from an old Core i3 530. This absolutely blows it away, as you'd expect.Converting blu-rays to x.265 using Handbrake with RF ~20 using the "medium" preset I get a little over 12 frames per second on average (no overclock). I tried the "slow" preset and was getting 5-6 fps, which is too slow to maintain my sanity. I never even bothered trying video conversion on my old i3 so I don't really have anything to compare it with.I'm using a Corsair Hydro H80i GT for cooling and it idles around 84F (~70F ambient). Peak temperature while encoding (CPU between 95 and 99% usage) seems to be 127F. Not using any special thermal grease.I tried the auto-overclock option in my motherboard's bios and that just forced the cores to their turbo-boost speed of 4.4 Ghz. Haven't played with any *real* overclocking yet.Can't wait to get a i7-6950X and see what that can do. :-)

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2014
Reviews: Very fast processor that will run anything. Will work great for most average users with the stock heat sink, however, be forewarned it will get very hot. With the stock heat sink on Prime 95 version 26 it would easily get up to 95-99 C and throttle back. While gaming it would hover around high 70s C. Disabling HyperThreading and Turboboost would clock it back to 4.0 GHz instead of 4.4 GHz which helps temps if you don't have an after market cooler. Around 85 C on Prime 95 and high 60s C during gaming with these disabled.Installed a Noctua nh-u12s which drastically help keep better temps which I recommend doing. With this cooler installed I get around mid 70s C on Prime 95 and around mid 50s C during gaming with HT and Turboboost enabled.While the stock cooler will work fine in most instances even for gaming, I would recommend to purchase an aftermarket one if you plan on pushing the CPU for extended periods or any overclocking what so ever.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2015
Reviews: Great processor in the 1150 chipset. I didn't realize how big a difference it would make going from an AMD 8350 to this. Games that wouldn't run on the 8350 ran great on this. I thought there was something wrong with Crysis or Mass Effects port to PC. It was that the 8350 wasn't good enough. The memory and gpu being the same or very close the only reason for the huge difference in playability was this chipset. I should have known because I had Crysis running on an older I7 960 with an old 1 gig gpu( really old 5 years old). If you want to game and want something that will probably work well for the next few years this is a good choice. Save your pennies, don't buy AMD, the difference between this and the FX8350 is night and day. I leave OC on auto and use the stock fan, it gets warm buy survives for now, eventually Ill get a 90mm cooler from Noctua.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsGood choice for high performance computing.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2014
Reviews: Pretty good choice.  I was going to make sure I can run virtualization (Windows 7 and Oracle VirtualBox) and I can with this one.  The BIOS has some additional features that are enabled due the "K" designation of the CPU.  I could not be happier with my choice.  The fan that comes with the CPU is probably the noisiest fan inside of my case, but since it is inside of the case, I guess it is reasonable.  If I need to overclock, I will buy a different fan, but certainly not for the noise it is making as it is completely tolerable.  I decided to go with the Video built in to the CPU (Intel 4600) and did not buy a separate video card.  Win7 Performance Index for video is 6.7, far better than what I was getting on my old machine.  Processor performance Index is 7.8 (maximum possible performance index number is 7.9 which is what I'm getting on my Samsung 840 EVO SSD)

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsFast. Very, very fast.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2015
Reviews: Asus Gryphon Z9716-gig Crucial DDR3512-gig Crucial SSDAMD Radeon R7770 1-gig DDR5No issues with initial setup; the motherboard ran with it.Boot time for Windows 7 Ultimate is about 8-seconds from pressing the power button. Installing Windows took less than an hour, including installing all of the various drivers, which required frequent reboots. 4-months later system continues to fly.One thing I love: Immediately after logging into Windows, I can open Chrome and start browsing, despite other programs continuing to load in the background. On my i5 laptop, Chome will often take 30-seconds or more to load while the system finishes starting background apps.Starcraft II, Diablo III, SimCity (2013) all run with maximum graphics at 1080p resolution, without any lag, and I frequently leave chrome open on the second monitor for reference.I used the stock Intel fan and have not done any overclocking--it's just not necessary with this CPU (although I'm sure it could be fun for benchmark purposes).

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsRuns hot with stock cooler
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2015
Reviews: It's very fast and a great value. Hard to say much more about it than that.My one complaint is that it runs VERY HOT with the stock fan/heat sink installed. Even without overclocking, the stock cooler couldn't keep it under 90-95C at full load, which is totally unacceptable. I reseated it and cleaned/reapplied thermal compound multiple times just to make sure it wasn't my mistake. A gigantic third party heat sink (Cooler Master Hyper 212 EVO) brought the temperature down to about 65C, which seems to be about as good as it gets for this processor without liquid cooling. It's not a huge additional expense, but it makes me wonder why they include the stock cooler at all. It's just extra stuff to throw away, and I bet it could have been a few bucks cheaper without it.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2014
Reviews: I installed this in my new rig and everything is so fast, it is a huge change from myIntel Core i7-870 Processor 2.93 GHz 8 MB Cache Socket LGA1156with 8GB of RAM.-Corsair Carbide Series White 500R Mid Tower Computer Case (CC-9011013-WW)-Gigabyte Black Edition LGA 1150 Intel Z97 HDMI SATA 6Gb/s USB 3.0 ATX Intel Motherboards GA-Z97X-UD5H-BK-Corsair Vengeance  16GB (2x8GB)  DDR3 1600 MHz (PC3 12800) Desktop Memory (CMZ16GX3M2A1600C10)-Cooler Master Hyper 212 EVO - CPU Cooler with 120mm PWM Fan (RR-212E-20PK-R2)-Crucial MX100 256GB SATA 2.5" 7mm (with 9.5mm adapter) Internal Solid State Drive CT256MX100SSD1- Windows 8.1I do not manually overclock but I believe the motherboard above runs it slightly overclocked by default.  Temperatures are cool and performance is stable.  I'm glad I went with the components that I did, especially this CPU.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsReally gets the job done
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2016
Reviews: Really gets the job done. I'm a power user, with, typically, Outlook, Word, Excel, several browser windows, plus some serious database applications of my own, all running at the same time, and my old laptop REALLY bogged down. This processor, combined with an SSD boot drive, makes life SO much more pleasant. I've checked the Windows resource meter and I'm not even beginning to bog it down.Because I wasn't sure whether I needed it or not, I went with most internet recommendations and bought an aftermarket fan/heat sink that is much better than what comes with the processor. I don't overclock and I am now very confident that I did not in fact need that extra cooling. I think what came with the processor would have been fine and unless you are overclocking and really stressing the CPU I doubt you will either. If you do it's very easy to add one when needed.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsJoin the PC Master Race, we have cookies.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2015
Reviews: This CPU is insane. The 8 threads definitely makes a difference in multitasking, (There's plenty of YouTube videos on that). I put this in my gaming rig and it runs games even GTA V on very high settings with my GTX 760. I am NOT an Intel fanboy, my previous CPU to this was an AMD but I gotta say Intel took the cake in this build. But I will say, you don't need this for gaming, the Intel Pentium anniversary edition (a dual core non hyper threaded chip) runs games very similar to this CPU. Games usually don't utilize 4 core and certainly not 8 threads. If you want a CPU that's quad core and this is out of your budget check out the i5 4690k it runs games and the EXACT fps as this one (again YouTube videos on that as well)To summarize this is a very strong very fast chip. Great for gaming and multitasking. Pretty decent on video editing because of the hyperthreading.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThis is the face of power!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2016
Reviews: Oh my, what happened to your face???  This is the face of POWAH!Blazing fast speeds for an awesome price.  It's not very often you get this much bang for your buck.  I put this in my new PC build and it's awesome.  My motherboard uses OC genie and it overclocks this processor at 4.4GHz, and with the Zalman heat sink this rarely goes over 40C for all 4 processors.  Both I would recommend highly if your system can support it.  The only cons I can think of is that it uses a lot of power to run, and that the stock heat sink that comes with it does not look like it could support an overclocked processor.  All in all, if you are looking for a CPU upgrade and this bad boy will fit your motherboard, and the Zalman CPU Cooler CNPS9500AT fits in your case, it's worth the upgrade.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K

Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2023
Reviews: It wasn't new, it does test correctly, and works.  Just got me mad, that it was advertised as new, it came in a cardboard box, (if it was new, why not in the original Intel Box as shown on posting) and the CPU itself had lock marks on the CPU from being locked down into a socket.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsIt runs beautifully. My computer start up time is around 10-15 ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2016
Reviews: Installing this thing was probably the most nerve racking thing about assembling my computer.  I connected this to an ASUS ROG Maximus VII Hero.  It runs beautifully.  My computer start up time is around 10-15 seconds and programs open up almost instantly.  I did not use the fan included with this.  I'm not sure I would recommend doing that ESPECIALLY if you're overclocking.  I have mine running on a water cooled system with two dedicated fans.  Actually I have been using this for about 8 months now and still love it.  I'm not an expert.  In fact, this was my first build and it was an awesome experience.  This little guy is kind of costly but if you're looking for a little future proofing, this might be a good way to go.  RAM can be upgraded later as it advances.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsthis thing is pretty amazing. I was using AMD Bulldozer before this ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2014
Reviews: Paired with my 240GB SSD and 8GB of 1600 Ram, this thing is pretty amazing.  I was using AMD Bulldozer before this i7 and the difference is simply incredible.  I really havn't even been close to using its potential yet.  Have not over clocked it yet.  Temps are around 41C idle in my Raven RVZ01 with a Noctua L9i cooler on top of it.  Its sitting in a gold plated Gigabyte Gaming 5 Mini ITX MB, which I must say is pretty awesome as well.  But, my god, this combination of components is amazing.  No GPU yet, but I am saving to fit a GTX 980 Reference in the Raven.  I want the best Mini ITX system, and this CPU for 1150 pinout is the best.  Maybe in 2 or 3 years I'll consider 2011 and go get some DDR4, but I'd rather wait for the price on that stuff to come down.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsGood for overclocked gaming and/or 3D workstations
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2014
Reviews: Most current chip for 1150 socket is great. Also called Devil's Canyon, the chip is easy to overclock with Asus' Duel Intelligent software -- it's best to overclock with this software, rather than from within the bios-- that comes with the 97-a board (you don't need to use this board, but it is cheap and easy to overclock). Cost effective for the amount of processing you get, especially if you are working with 3D modeling programs that utilize the CPU more that the GPU such as Revit. You can get away with not having a discrete GPU since this chip has graphic capability built in, but I am assuming that most people would be getting this chip for gaming or working in 3D design/rendering, so discrete GPU would be a must.Runs well, no major issues, fast, easy to install, pretty straight forward. Additionally, if you want to overclock, go with something Corsair H100i instead of the in box heat sink unit.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 stars"Up to 4.40 GHz", but actually runs stock at 4.00 GHz. Still works great though! Very fast processing
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2015
Reviews: I would have given this product 5 stars, but I am disappointed with the way that it's advertised. The headline says "up  to 4.40 GHz", but what does that really mean? I have to assume that means you can overclock it to 4.40 GHz safely, but running stock in my PC, it runs at only 4.00 GHz. It should have read more like "4.00 GHz, OC to 4.40 GHz". I learned my lesson this time, fool me once, shame on you. I would ask that the product be more accurately portrayed, but otherwise, the product works amazingly well. I upgraded from a 3.2 GHz Quad Core Intel Chip, and the performance increase is very noticeable. Everything on my PC now happens when I click without a big lag time like before.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsA brief review and benchmark
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2016
Reviews: (The CPU has been in use for nearly half of a year as of this review)I purchased the 4790K for a PC build I was doing for myself. I have build several "gaming" computers at this point so I have a bit of experience. The product arrived fully functional and was installed into an MSI Z97 SLI Krait Edition motherboard.This processor never misses a beat. I use the computer for primarily gaming but also for CAD and related engineering uses. For these purposes the CPU stays cool and under-utilized on the stock CPU cooler. I have some benchmarks bellow.Cinebench R15852 Multi-Core173 Single-CoreOverall, I am very happy with this CPU and will be soon overclocking it. If you are just gaming or enthusiast video editing or something along those lines, this CPU is more than enough.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSo i feel perfectly fine pusing it to the limit
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2014
Reviews: OC mine to 4.7 ghzsuperfast processingI need 1.36 volts to get 47x multiplier and 100 bclk but if I downclock it  to 4.65 ghz (46x multiplier and 101 bclk I can keep voltage around 1.31 --The thing is, I paid intel $25 extra for overclocking insurance so if I burn out my CPU by applying too much voltage OCing I am covered under warranty. So i feel perfectly fine pusing it to the limit. I am stable on prime 95 (dont use 28, use prime ver 26.? because it works better with Haswell--the newest prime is bad for haswell, causing temps to rise too much with even minor OC). Google which version is the exact one to use, it slips my mind at this moment.Of course, throw out the stock heat sink when it arrives. I am using a corsair h100i and it works magic. If your case cant handle it then use the h80i.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790K Processor (8M Cache, up to 4.40 GHz) BX80646I74790K
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsWorked great easy installation and everything worked flawlessly plug and play ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
Reviews: Product Itself: Worked great easy installation and everything worked flawlessly plug and play have purchased this over a year ago.Opinion:A regular 4790K will cost you roughly 320 EUR, say 339 USD. A binned 4.8 MHz model is in the 375 USD range and the 5 GHz models will pass 400 USD. As such a binned processor is more expensive, but does come with that very nice guaranteed clock frequency.
