Reviews: Best bang for your buck by a long shot.The bundled cooler is obviously bare bones so do yourself a great justice and go aftermarket; I teamed it with an Arctic 13 Pro and it idles at 27 degrees when clocked at 4.2GHz (auto OC on an Asus P8Z77-V).If you can make use of the threads then go for it otherwise the i5 is perhaps sufficient at 2/3rds of the price.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 1, 2014
Reviews: This was the top end i7 at the time when I purchased, I bought it to overclock with the combination of my CoolerMaster case, and the corsair h100 hydro cooler, if you want to see what this i7 is capable it's a highly recommended setup and when at full OC it's faster than my friends i7-4770k (which is the newer version) very happy, oh and strongly recommend the attic mx5 thermal paste to keep it nice and cool!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in France on January 7, 2013
Reviews: Le processeur pour PC de bureau Intel Core i7-3770K (3.5 GHz) offre des performances intelligentes avec turbo pour regarder des films, créer et retoucher du contenu vidéo, partager des photos et bien plus encore ! Offrant plus de puissance lorsque vous en avez besoin et des graphismes intégrés de grande qualité, le processeur Intel Core i7 troisième génération doté de la technologie Intel Turbo Boost 2.0 vous permet de naviguer entre le visionnage de vos films HD et la retouche photo ou vidéo, et bien plus encore. Des performances visuellement intelligentes avec turbo.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in Germany on March 7, 2021
Reviews: iMac ende 2012 eingebaut

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 12, 2013
Reviews: Slots into my P8Z77-Pro V motherboard easy without applying any force whatsoever.  Even putting the cooler over is just as easy and no need to screw it in but rather plastic clips that get locked into place when pushed down. Tested my new built PC and saw the lovely "American Megatrends" logo on my monitor and the BIOS said its detected the new CPU.No problems, so I'm happy.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 4, 2012
Reviews: Got this to party with a gigabyte z77 board and 16gig of samsung Green ddr3 ram and chilled by a noctua nh-d14, I ain't got a graphics card yet but so far things are getting very raunchy down there. It seems every time I buy something from amazon they reduce the price 2 days later, this was 254 now it's 242, why you do this to me amazon, why?

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 12, 2013
Reviews: I installed this (without any problems) back in April and it has worked without a hitch ever since. I don't overclock, look at energy usage or speeds so my 5 star rating is for the facts that this was easy to install, I've had no problems and have no lag in any game I've tried.Sits at 19 degrees with my corsair H80i cooler. Sat about 45 with the supplied heatsink.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in France on February 18, 2015
Reviews: acheté d'occasion pour une upgrade, problème de description par son vendeur, excellent CPU pour le socket 1155 d'ancienne génération. Bon produit. Conseil si vous achetez d'occasion: contacter le vendeur AVANT l'achat pour poser toutes ses questions et s'assurer de ce qu'on achète/qui est vendu pour pouvoir faire un choix éclairé en connaissance de cause.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 11, 2014
Reviews: I bought this for my ultimate pc machine. This works well but i haven't really had anything yet that has troubled it. I am doing a lot of CAD work and it doesn't seem to slow down at all. An i5 would probably have been just as good but this will hopefully mean that I don't have to upgrade for many years to come. It comes with instructions and fits in easily.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 9, 2013
Reviews: Decided after many happy years with AMD to go back to INTEL this time, slotted into the asus p8z77-m pro with corsair 16gb 1600MHZ vengeance dd3 memory, make sure you use paste on the intel cooler and its fine. my last cpu was a AMD X6 BLACK 1100 T 3.3, A great cpu too, but with the I7 everything seems so much more quicker and smoother :)

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in Germany on June 17, 2014
Reviews: Da ich aktuell keine sonderlich anspruchsvollen Anwendungen nutze kann ich nichts zur Leistungsfähigkeit des Prozessors sagen.Bereuen tue ich meine Kaufentscheidung jedoch nicht und würde ihn jederzeit wieder kaufen^^Mein System hat einen merklichen Leistungsschub nach der Aufrüstung bekommen.Da ich jedoch alle relevanten Komponenten (Board, Prozessor und Arbeitsspeicher) gewechselt habe kann ich nicht detailiert sagen wer genau diesen Schub gebracht hat.Sollte ich den Prozessor mal an seine Leistungsgrenze bringen (^^) werde ich mich hier etwas präzieser äußern.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 12, 2012
Reviews: Overall, very satisfied. My only concern was the locking mechanism is a bit awkward. On my Gigabit mobo, I didn't feel a solid "lock down" on my heatsink installation. The temps are fine, but it would have been nice to feel a proper 'click'.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in France on March 27, 2021
Reviews: très bien

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 20, 2013
Reviews: If you are reading this you are looking for performance.Always get the K version of the Intel CPU's - It means that the CPU is UNLOCKED and flies in the 4++Ghz range!This gem is amazingly powerful and just amazingly feature rich.Beyond recommendation.TIP: Add it to a Asus P8Z77-I Deluxe (mini-itx 17cm square) with a BitFenix Prodigy mini-itx case for a portable gaming power house!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770K Quad-Core Processor 3.5 GHz 8 MB Cache LGA 1155
Review Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 15, 2013
Reviews: The processor is quick even when running 3 or 4 application's the performance doesn't drop off much. If your overclocking definitely get an aftermarket cooler I have a hyper 212 evo and the CPU runs well within limits at 4.2 GHz. If you do video encoding try and get software that supports quick sync the difference in speed is makes it well worth it.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsPowerful but *CHECK COMPATIBILITY FIRST*
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
Reviews: I bought this over the 6700k because I edit video in addition to gaming.  The 6700k is cheaper, but the 6 cores of the 6800k is well worth it and the newer architecture is great peace of mind for future-proofing.*MAKE SURE YOU CHECK BOARD COMPATIBILITYI purchased an MSi X99A Sli Plus Motherboard initially, but had to return it because it wasn't compatible without a bios update.  MSi's website lists it as compatible and a customer service rep assured me it would be out of the box, but it wasn't.  Ended up being a huge hassle.I recommend the new X99 boards from Asus.  I got the X99-A II.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsThis was a nice upgrade from my i5 6600k for workloads and was ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2017
Reviews: I'm loving the 6800k so far. I'm a student who loves to game and does graphics work as a hobby. This was a nice upgrade from my i5 6600k for workloads and was about the same in terms of gaming performance. Be aware though, Broadwell-E does not overclock as well as Haswell-E so if you're into high per core speeds, this might not be for you. Currently running at 4.1 GHz with an NZXT X52 Kraken cooler.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsBest Deal For Both Gaming & Virtualization!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2017
Reviews: - 6 Cores / 12 Threads are more than enough to satisfy your gaming and development needs!- I was able to hit 4.4 GHz @ 1.35v with my current build:> Motherboard:ASUS LGA2011-v3 5-Way Optimization SafeSlot ATX Motherboard ROG STRIX X99 GAMING> Memory:Corsair Vengeance 16GB (2x8GB) DDR4 3000 (PC4-24000) C15 for DDR4 Systems, Red LED (CMU16GX4M2C3000C15R)> CPU Cooler:Nepton 280L - 140 mm - Liquid cooling system radiator with fan> CPU Cooler Fans: 2 xCorsair Air Series SP 140 LED Red High Static Pressure Fan Cooling - twin pack

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsA beast of a CPU
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2016
Reviews: Excellent processor for multi-tasking and content creation. Overclocked this baby to a conservative 4.0Ghz on an H100i v2 Corsair AIO cooler at 1.35v, and runs at 60C under load and 30C idling.Twitch streaming, Handbrake encoding, and heavy let's plays and gaming have got nothing on this beast. Definitely worth the price.Warning: this requires a very good cooler and a lot of voltage to overclock, and even then, you most likely will not see anything higher than 4.2Ghz (base clock is 3.4Ghz at multi-core performance). Have realistic power and performance expectations.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2016
Reviews: You can't really go wrong with an Intel processor these days, especially when there is no real competition. It's a tough choice between this and the 6700K (skylake) and it depends on what kind of workload you're going to throw at it.That said, 4 stars from me because it doesn't overclock particularly well, and the lack of competition is pushing the price up a but too much.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSince I have the latest gtx 1070 it seemed like a good idea
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2017
Reviews: As someone that has always used AMD CPU I decided to go for intel because the latest round of GPU optimize on 3.0 pcie slots. Currently there isn't the "best" support for that on AMD supported motherboards. Since I have the latest gtx 1070 it seemed like a good idea. I have had no issues with this cpu and it runs super cool with just a 240mm radiator. Not to mention the OS is on a SSD and start up time is almost instant.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2016
Reviews: Intel Core i7-6800KPros:-6 cores is amazing for multitasking, and multithreaded applications.-28 PCI-e lanes , more than you get with 6700k.( 20 PCI-e ).-It could come 4.0GHz out of the box and still run coolCons:-28 pcie lanes instead of 40 compared to other broadwell-e processors.-Costly compared to 5820k.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsChews through Adobe Premiere and Photoshop like a pro
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2017
Reviews: Bought to upgrade from a Haswell i5-4690 stock in an MSI Z97 DDR3. Got this new one up to a stable 4.1 overclock on 1.32V with a ThermalTake Water 3.0 RGB cooler. Used with an MSI X99A SLI Krait and (2) 8GB DDR4 Corsair Vengeance LED modules at 3000MHz with XMP. Chews through Adobe Premiere and Photoshop like a pro. The extra cores also help out in some games, but not all.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)
Review Title: 3.0 out of 5 starsGreat CPU, but died in less than 6 months..
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2017
Reviews: Very fast CPU. Handles any job you throw at it. Downfall it's only 28 PCI Lane, not 40 like most.. The second downfall is it died completely in less than 6 months. I never had a CPU (only used to buy AMD) die on me. It took Intel about 2-3 days to get me a new one sent to me, costing me $25 for shipping. Now I'm worried if it's going to die again in 6 months.

Product Title: Intel Boxed Core i7-6800K Processor (15M Cache, up to 3.60 GHz) FCLGA2011-3 (BX80671I76800K)

It is 20% overclocked and still runs nice and cool.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSi quieres un PC Gamer??
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2014
Reviews: Perfecto esta es mi configuracion y todo lo corre sin problemas... Si no tienes una GPU puedes usar la GPU interna de este i7 4770k que es una intel 4600 y te correra juegos como PayDay 2, Left 4 Dead 2 y Outlast en una resolcion muy aceptable.. Esta es la configuracion que tengo en este momento y todo es perfecto:-Intel Core i7-4770-ASUS ATX DDR3 2600 LGA 1150 Motherboards MAXIMUS VI FORMULA-INTEL 120 GB 2.5" Internal Solid State Drive 2.5IN-Corsair Vengeance 8GB (1x8GB) DDR3 1600 MHz-Asus Black 12X BD-ROM 16X DVD-ROM 48X CD-ROM SATA Internal Blu-Ray Drive-Corsair Hydro Series Extreme Performance Liquid CPU Cooler H80i-WD Blue 1 TB Desktop Hard Drive: 3.5 Inch, 7200 RPM, SATA 6 Gb/s-GPU= AMD r9 290x

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsGood CPU for ESXi build
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2013
Reviews: I built myself small form factor ESXi box using this CPU. It is a good solution because it has GPU inside and there is no need to buy dedicated graphic card. This CPU supports VT-d with appropriate motherboard. I have no complains with performance, VM boots from SSD storage within 1-2 sec and currently running 14 VMs.Here are the specs for my whole build:MB: Asrock Z87M Extreme4 (supports VT-d)CPU: i7-4770MEM: Corsair Vengeance 32GB (4x8GB)Storage: Samsung Electronics 840 Pro Series 2.5-Inch 256 GB SATA 6GB SSDNetwork: 2x INTEL - NETWORKING PRO/1000PT 10/100/1000BTX GBE PCIE COPPER SERVER 2PORTCase: Cooler Master Elite 342 with Cooler Master Silent Pro M2 420WAlso have Dell Perc5i inside which is not in use for now.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsFast and works well
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2013
Reviews: This is a great CPU, and when combined with my Asus Z87 motherboard, I was able to easily tweak it to 11% faster, sometimes even able to clock 4.1 GHz and very little cooling needed. The additional Intel graphics don't seem to do much for me. I tried it out to see how it was, but it lacked so many features that even my old graphics card (two years old) easily outmatches it. As for processing power, I could hardly ask for more, but I was expecting more from the included graphical side.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThe best Intel has to offer in a consumer chip
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2013
Reviews: Yes, Intel makes the i7-4770K, which is slightly faster and overclockable, but that lacks some of the new instructions for virtualization and transactional memory that the 4th Generation (Haswell) Core chips introduced. I have no intentions of overclocking my CPU and as such got a bit more of a workstation-class chip for a lower price. Seemed like a win-win to me. Other than the K variant of this CPU, as of right now there isn't a faster Haswell chip that Intel makes, and it's reasonably priced. Was easy to install and am very happy with it.The only reason I can think of to not use this is if you really believe you need to overclock your CPU.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2014
Reviews: This processor installed very easy.  Powered up on first try.  And runs incredibly fast and is very efficient.  I mated this with a new 1150 motherboard (Gigabyte GA-Z87X-UD5H) and a new power supply (Corsair Professional Series  HX 750 Watt ATX/EPS Modular 80 PLUS Gold) tested with this chip. After the set time frame the whole system will hibernate and become silent.  When I want to start using the computer.  It wakes instantaneously and I am ready to go.  The only negative I see, is that the instruction manual could be better.  It is not very descriptive.  It does direct you to a website for installation instruction.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsWhat can I say that hasn't been said
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2013
Reviews: This is the latest from Intel.  The new Haswell processor.  If we ignore needing a new motherboard in order to install this new LGA 1150 chip then I cannot find anything negative to say and can only emphasize what others already say about this chip.  Easy to install, fast, cooler than the LGA 2010 it replaced by a couple of degrees C, oh did I mention its fast??  ;-)I opted for the non-K version since I don't overclock.Build:Asus VI Gene32GB RAMEVGA 680Creative Labs ZLSI 3650 SE6x3tb RAID 5Crucial M4 256 SSD boot driveIntel mPCIe wireless/Bluetooth

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsno brainer/ If you aren't planning on overclocking... buy this one. its a beast
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2013
Reviews: Really this is the one to get.Using the new internal graphics... I was really surprised JUST how well it did. It's been great! And by the way, I'm a videographer and editing using this as a GPU was not as horrible as one would think. It actually worked as well as a low grade GPU.Ive actually even seen some real world reviews where this processor alone beat out an 6 core AMD processor and a ATI GPU (take with some salt but you wouldnt expect it to even be a competition)I'm happy! If I do another 4 core build... I'll be using this CPU

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGreat the second time around
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2014
Reviews: this processor is perfectly fine, works great.HOWEVER the first time i ordered it, the processor i got had glue on several parts of the contact face, including on the contact plates themselves. Needless to say, i returned this and got a new one, which was not even the same design to be honest. Would give five stars but obviously there was a bit of an issue the first time around

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2014
Reviews: I need you need to build a high-end workstation or gaming PC, today, this is probably the CPU you want. Hyperthreading is the main difference between the i7 and the i5, and it does make a real-world difference in heavy-workload apps. The on-chip Intel HD4600 graphics is also quite capable, as long as you don't expect high framerates in AAA games at high-quality @ 1080p; if you do, buy a separate video card.This is the stable "non-K" 4770 version, which means it's slightly cheaper than the 4770K because it isn't over-clockable.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsVery Heavy-Load capable, and fast
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2014
Reviews: This CPU is extremely fast for not being able to overclock. The stock cooler, as always, is not good at all for what Haswell requires in terms of controlling TDP (the heat generated by the CPU). You will have to invest in an aftermarket cooler, as Haswell is known to generate more heat than it's predecessor.If you plan to build a high-end gaming PC, I suggest you go with the K version, as this CPU may bottleneck your system if you don't know how to disable the power-saving features.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2013
Reviews: This processor is great, handles everyday task without breaking a sweat. I don't usually run benchmarks but I do notice a decrease in loading times and processing. Although the HD 4600 can't output 144 hz vis dual link cable, I'm sure when my dedicated graphics arrive I can utilize it. If there's anyone who knows how to make HD 4600 output 144hz@1080p, please do tell me :)There are plenty of prrofessional reviews out there, but I can tell you that a cross gen jump is worth it.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2013
Reviews: I love it! My new build wouldn't be complete without this 4th generation quad core! It runs the four cores and 4 virtual cores and is fast, fast... I am OC at 3.6 with the cooling fan that comes with the core.. I have a better fan just working out logistics but I am beyond thrilled to get what I am getting with this. Scoring a 7.9 exp score from windows with my 2tb geforce gpu and THAT is keeping me from a 8.1.. Happy customer here...

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2013
Reviews: If you are looking an incredibly powerful, fast and efficient cpu then this is it! Got a 7.8 on the windows experience index. I am an architecture major and bought this cpu to help improve render times. Its incredible to watch it hyperthread to 8 cores@ 3.7 ghz. A lot can get done quickly with that! Rendered the same image as I did with my 2core i5 2.9ghz laptop that took 20 hours. My new computer with this cpu did it in 3.5 hours. Just incredible improvement.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2013
Reviews: Upgraded from an AMD Athlon II X3.  My wife does photo editing in Photoshop and I rip Blu Rays and encode them to an HTPC format.  This upgrade has reduced my encode times by as much as 90% which is incredible.  Photoshop can process filters and such much faster than before, again, a reduction of as much as 90%.  My wife was hesitant when I suggested an $800 upgrade which would essentially rebuild the computer but she has been very happy with the noticeably faster processor.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsPowerful, Trusted, and Durable.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2014
Reviews: When you see Intel you should be sold. Intel costs more, but provide not only superior performance, outstanding durability, and they rarely have issues, but when you do have an issue you don't feel dreadful because you know how amazing Intel provides their support and information. AMD can't compare when it comes to Intel. But if you're on a budget, you'll get budget performance, and you'll peek towards AMD. I enjoy paying a little more for better performance which is exactly why I go to Intel.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2014
Reviews: My build:this core i7,MSI H87M-G43 board8gb RAM,Kingston 120gb SSD, andmy old SATA HD.No additional video card.  Windows 7 installed on SSD.  Windows performance index:  CPU 7.7,  Graphics 6.5 (with on board video card). CPU fan runs smooth and quiet, a sign of well controlled CPU temperature. This may not be the chip with best price-performance ratio.  However, the extra cost buys you predictability, and a trouble free building experience

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsIntel Core i7-4770 LGA 1150 processor.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2017
Reviews: Very nice CPU. Runs cool and clean. Some say this is a Intel 3770 in a LGA 1150 envelop,  yes it is. Just a little more refined. It's big brother the Intel 4790 will smoke it, but not by much, heat is the problem with the latter.This processor went on a Asus Z97 board with my usual attire. A perfect system for me to "scoot" around with.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4770 Quad-Core Desktop Processor 3.4 GHZ LGA 1150 8 MB Cache BX80646I74770

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsExcellent Upgrade for OEM Prebuilt PC's with 4th Gen Intel Processors
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2019
Reviews: Bought one of these used for about $180 to upgrade from the Intel Core i5-4430 that came with my HP Envy 700-074.  Not the best value on the market compared to the Ryzen 5 2400G or 3400G, but offers similar performance to those CPU's.  At the time of this review, those are much better values for building new PC's and include an upgrade path to CPU's with more cores, something that isn't doable with older Intel consumer platforms.The additional clock speed and hyperthreading definitely allow for snappier and smoother performance.  Gaming performance is improved massively compared to the i5-4430 when it comes to the latest AAA games, with a 15-30 percent improvement in performance in older games that have little use for more than four threads.Installing it was easy.  All it involved was swapping out the i5-4430 and inserting this CPU in its place along with a fresh application of thermal paste and reusing the original OEM HP cooler.  It runs slightly hotter than the i5, but temps stayed below 70c even under intensive testing.  Overall, I am very pleased with this processor.The i7-4790k was still over $200 at the time I did the upgrade, and that would have been the CPU I would have gone for had it been closer to the non-K version in price due to its additional performance.September 2020 Update: The PC this went in has been retired as of June 2020, but I enjoyed the short time I had it with this processor.  My only regret is that I purchased the processor near the tail end of the HP Envy 700-074's useful life.  I have since replaced it with a Ryzen 5 3600-based iBUYPOWER prebuilt, and I'm enjoying it as much as I enjoyed the Envy 700-074 in its early days of use in the fall of 2013.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsFast, Cool and Excellent balance of cost vs performance
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2015
Reviews: What an upgrade!  When I build my new machine in July 2014, I did lots of research on boards and chips, looking at power, performance and cost.  This chip is an excellent upgrade for people replacing systems that are a few years old.  I upgraded from an AMD based platform and needed some serious speed gain for my editing needs, as the software has become heavier and heavier.I landed on the i7-4790.  Didnt spend the extra money for the K version, because I am using this for real world apps, and dont play games at all (dont have the spare time).I ditched the factory Intel CPU cooler and went with a CoolerMaster EVO 212, after reading several other reviews on it, where in their tests it was keeping the chip cooler than water cooled setups.All in all, I am in love with this new setup.BUILD Sheet:Case: Corsair Carbide 300R Black - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006I2H0YSCPU: Intel i7-4790 - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00J56YSLMCPU Cooler: Cooler Master 212 EVO - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005O65JXIMotherBoard: ASUS Sabertooth Z97 Mk II - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00K2R6E10Additional Case Fan: Noctua NF-A14 PWM - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CP6QLY62x of Memory: Corsair Vengance DDR3 1600 (CMZGX3M2A1600C10R) - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008E3M4QSVideo: EVGA GeForce GTX760 ACX (02G-P4-2765-KR) http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00E0N49C8WiFi NIC: Rosewill RNWD-N9003PCe - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009VKON0SPower Supply (PSU): Corsair CX750 http://www.amazon.com/dp/B008RJZQSWBoot Drive (SSD for OS and Apps): Samsung EVO840 250GB http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00LMXBOP44x of Hard Drives (2 were re-used): WD Green 3TB http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004RORMF6CD/DVD/BluRay Drive (reused): Pioneer BCD-207DBK http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00I47O7AKAdditional Items:WiFi Router: TP-Link Archer C9 - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PDLRHFWColor Correction Tool: ColorMunki Display - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0055MBQOMMonitors (re-used): 2x Acer 23" 16:9 (next thing to be updated)

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsWorks Great for My Machine
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2016
Reviews: Built my entire computer through Amazon for less than it cost me to buy my Macbook Pro. This is the motherboard I decided on since it had two Ethernet connections that I could dedicate to CNC machines to avoid any crosstalk. By the time I write this I'm sure that they probably have come out with a better board, but what can you do , have to get on the marry-go-round sooner or later. My Case I chose is the Chenbro Rackmount 4U Server Chassis that accepts this board without any issues.Intel i74790 processor, NZXT aperture card reader, Corsair Vengeance 32 GB DDR3  RAM,Samsung slim internal disk drive, Corsair CXM 750 Watt power supply, Samsung 850 pro 512 GB SSD ,TP Link n900 wireless dual band pic express card, NZXT Sentry 3 touch screen fan controller with extra fans.  And a killer 4 monitor graphics card that I can't remember what it was now. Couldn't be happier with my setup, Being I haven't built a computer since the mid 90's it was really cool to see this come together without any issues at all, Definitely the way to go if you want a clean computer without any BS software preinstalled from the factory.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 1.0 out of 5 starsIt was just the wrong product
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2016
Reviews: I'm sure that if you get an i7-4790 processor, any customer, gamer and worker alike would love the product. However, I had a wonderfully odd experience with this product. The core came in the proper packaging, undamaged, installed perfectly fine. The actually writing on the core was indeed i7-4790, so everything stated this was the right product. Make sure you check what you have after getting your pc running. I made that mistake. Despite everything saying that this was an i7, and feeling comfortable making that purchase, the actually core, despite all the writing and packaging is actually a pentium g3258. I don't know what went wrong, but when I started downloading more taxing games like the recent gears of war, and titan fall 2, the games wouldn't run, even though an i7 should be perfect. Turns out I've had a pentium in disguise this whole time. Good times. Amazon has been helpful, saying that they'll provide a partial refund for the product, and I understand that, but just a word of warning if you purchase this. I think I might be the only one this has happened to so no worries. I ran AMD before all this and never had this type of problem, so maybe it was just a freak accident on intel's manufacturing end. Cool. I'm suffering for my errors now, just don't make the same mistake as me and believe all of the wordings on your packaging and processor. It might just be wrong.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsHardest To Install But That's My Fault.....
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
Reviews: I decided to get this CPU as the i7-4790k I had just got wasn't stable on my system. It might run fine for two days then lockup solid or it might not even stay up for 20 minutes before locking up. I tried a number of things that just didn't work for me. Since I like my CPUs to run stable most of the time, this  was just not for me. (If I ever get a new MB that's set up for overclocking, then I'm all set.) So I got this in today and shut down the my main gaming system and proceeded to get it installed. Right off the bat yellow blinking light on boot. I had taken all the steps I should but no dice first try. Redid the heat sink compound and reseated the H60 heat sink on the CPU.....Second attempt.....yellow blinking power light. Decided to check and see if the PS, MB, or CPU were bad. Took the old i5 and reinstalled it and it booted right up! Opps! I was beginning to think I'd got a bad chip. So back to the kitchen for one last try. This time I removed the BIOS battery to clear he BIOS just in case. When I had removed i5 and started to installed the i7 again, I noticed on the bottom some heat sink compound has gotten smeared over the very lower left side of the chip on a few contact points. Apparently when I installed it the first time, I had gotten some heat sink compound on the underside of the chip. Cleaned that area off with some alcohol then reinstalled it  again making sure to get the compound on the top of the chip only. Put the battery back in and back to the computer room. This time the system had the yellow blinking light again on the first try. So I decided let's give it one more try. Pressed the power bottom and just let it sit there. It went thru a number of quick false starts and then booted right up! I almost fell out of the chair. I had just about decided I had played chip roulette once to many times. Anyway, after that it has been running very stable and has failed to handle anything I've thrown at it. We'll see how it does over a long term but it is sure running and feeling solid now. Guess next time I'll be a bit more careful with the heat sink compound! (Reminds me of my 4790k..........)

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 3.0 out of 5 starsCHIP IS GREAT BUT THE COOLER IS CRAP AND DONT FIT BUT NONE OF THE RECOMENDED ONES WILL FIT IN MY CASE!! HELP
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2016
Reviews: Well for starters the stock intel cooler unit and its stupid plastic push pins wouldnt fit my hp pavilion 500-223w. memphis-S motherboard. Which clearly lists this CPU upgrade as compatible. My board has screw threading in the holes so the push pins wouldnt fit. So i just put the chip in the board with the cooler/fan it came with. which by the way was twice the size of the one that came with this cpu. the only difference was the copper plating that was on the stock intel cooler and mine was from an i3-4130 so it was all aluminum. but i was a little worried about the temps getting up to 60c while playing an old assassins creed game which isnt even a really power hungry game, and so ive been on a mission trying to find a new cooler for this that will fit into my HP pavilion case. its been all but impossible to find a good enough one that can fit without the heatsink being like 9 inches long (like the hyper 212 evo thats recomended with this) and i only have a square 6 inch radius space left inside my case where the cooler should be. so i figured id take my computer apart to see what these screw threadings were. I didnt know if the threadings were just in the holes or if it was a bracket. so when I took the whole entire computer apart just to get under the board and see what it was, i found a bracket in the back that has 3 screws which are whats holding the cpu mount and when i tried to take the bracket off I realized that I couldnt because without that, the clamps have nothing to stick to. so I tried to reverse it because the bracket has this huge indent groove on one side and a straight smooth side on the other. the smooth side is whats screwed to against the board. so i attempted to flip it around to where the indent was against the motherboard so i could still screw in the cpu mount clamps but also have enough room for the stock intel coolers pushpins into. which worked! but sadly after i put everything back together my computer wouldnt turn on right away i had to hold the power button down for it turn on then it went right to the start up repair in windows 10 and said it didnt recognize the cpu fan and then restarted and booted and as soon as windows loaded i went to click the intel gadget tool to check what the temp was, and it would just freeze all up and id have to restart it and try again i tried about 4 times before i just quit and reinstalled my original cooler and now everything is fine again as it was before i did all of this.. but still i have NO IDEA what im going to do about this issue. I almost wish i wouldve known this would be a problem before i went and spent $1200 upgrading this god awful PC that I bought at walmart over the last year.(I didnt know as much as i do now about computer and gradually upgrading each component one at a time, PSU, GPU, RAM, now the CPU. pretty much everything but the board its self) I wish I wouldve just bought the right stuff from the jump before buying this OEM crap! Cause i probably wouldnt be here. but at the time it seemed like a really good PC to me compared to my last one. Now im stuck with it and i went as far as buying this 300$  processor and now i have no way to fit the proper cooler in it and i cant use the one intel gave me with it because of the stupid push pins that wont fit. I guess next im going to have to buy a new case. Well gee i might as well just go buy a new motherboard and new version of windows and just put all the crap this computer came with back into it and use all the upgraded stuff on a completely new build!!!!!! And when i called HP for advice for the FIRST time in the whole year ive had this computer and never needed them for anything, they had the nerve to tell me that because i removed the CPU and other stock components that my warranty is now VOID!!!!! WHAT KIND OF CRAP IS THAT?! Smh.. I really cant win man. So now im stuck here wishing i wouldve just listened to one of my friends who told me to just build the PC myself from the start and I couldve avoided all of this. I just wish I didnt have so much limitation on what i could upgrade. Like my GPU i bought specifically to fit that CPU at the time cause i didnt think i would get a new CPU. Now when i go to get a new CPU i was limited to what i could choose cause it had to be FOR THAT HP BOARD. So this does suck. I guess it is what it is. Im just going to have to deal with it. I just have no clue how long this chip is going to last  now that i dont have the proper cooling for it. What a wasteeee. But so far the chip has been AWESOME at the CPU%!!! With apps and games that used to run my old i3 at 90% CPU, now barely puts a dent into this one! Even GTA 5 was only using about 20-30% CPU in task manager! THATS CRAZY my old cpu would be at a constant 99% while playing it lol.. So as far as the CHIP ITS SELF, ITS GREAT!!!!!! But only if you can maintain it with the proper cooler and board. Otherwise youll end up like me and spending a lot of money on something that you couldve put towards getting something better.. IF ANYONE CAN HELP OR ASSIST ME WITH SOME IDEAS PLEASE LET ME KNOW IM STUMPED ON WHAT KIND OF COOLER I CAN GET FOR THIS!!!! The first picture is the cooler that comes with this chip. and the second one is what came with my computer that im forced to use. If anyone has any ideas on what else i could get dont hesitate to respond!!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsA Very Pricey Processor...But Worth The Money
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2014
Reviews: Intel Core i7 processors can be quite pricey; at least I consider processors within the $300 price range to be pricey. But if you're looking to build a computer that will operate in the long run (and use up less Wattage), Intel would be your best bet. I'm using this processor for a gaming computer, but I anticipate doing video editing (some time in the future...I think).But even if I weren't doing video editing (I keep reading that Intel processors are recommend for that), I also intended my computer to be a reliable workstation, in addition to playing games. This processor is so friggin' fast.I'll grant that even for basic work, it's over-powered, but I'd rather have that than under-powered. Hopefully, this processor will last in the long run.Be aware, though, that this processor is not accompanied with a "K" (an indicator that it is unlocked for overclocking). Nevertheless, I didn't see any need to overclock, even for playing computation-intensive games like Crysis. (The Graphics Card would be the determinant factor...I think.)P. S.: The Intel Stock Cooling Fan that came with the processor is quite reliable...and...I think quiet. (It's brand new.) I could tell because I was using silent Enermax fans. So far, it has had no problems since three weeks go when it was installed into my system. Unless you're into overclocking, this cooling fan should be adequate...maybe a little more than adequate for the job. It's quite easy to install because it's got it's own thermal paste installed on the heatsink base; if you're not sure how to install it, do a dry run because if you installed it wrong, you have to clean off the paste and re-apply it again. Do a dry-run installation to avoid the hassle; but if there's a plastic covering, be sure to remove it before installation.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790

I say this because this is the essential meat to my gaming rig I just built and it's what I'm running all the latest games at.I won't go into further tech information of what I'm running unless you want to ask me later, but for the money of this CPU paired up with solid components around it, it can't be beat for the price.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGreat CPU, crappy cooler -- Get yourself an aftermarket cooler!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2016
Reviews: I know what you must be thinking:  4 stars?  That CPU is a beast (even if it can't overclock).  And you would be right, this is a strong and efficient CPU, which made me glad that I passed up an FX series chip/board and went the extra for this instead.  But I'm not just rating the CPU with this review -- I'm rating the CPU and the cooler that came with it (the entire purchase).This CPU is paired with an MSI PC Mate Z97 board, with the boot/OS drive on an ADATA SSD.  From power-on to sign-in is about 5-6 seconds for me (faster than my Chromebook, which can be usable in about 6-8 seconds from a cold start).  The start-up configuration that I have is similar to what I have set up for others.  I can multitask like a villain and not even blink an eye (music or YouTube, image manipulation, video rendering, streaming).But then we come to the included cooler.  It sucks.  The downside to my multitasking adventures is that my CPU does run up into the mid to high 60's (in C) easily, and frequently dips into the 70's.  That's not acceptable in a room that is deliberately kept 5 degrees cooler than the rest of the house (rest of the house is set for 69 F).  There are no obstructions around the PC case, and I have numerous fans on the case to ensure adequate ventilation.  I've noted from others who own the same CPU that they had to go with an aftermarket cooler for better temps.  I will shortly be doing the same.  For this, and only this issue, this product loses a star.Overall, I am happy with the performance of the i7-4790, and would recommend it to anyone who isn't interested in overclocking, but needs the ability to smoothly multitask.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790

However, this thing averages 3.7-3.8ghz out of the box with the intel turbo runnning. I have it paired with a gtx 1060, 16gb ram, and a ssd. I can run PUBG at a silky smooth 70-90fps. Atilla total war comes in at around 50-60 with over 1000 units on the field, all max settings.Only reason I didn’t give 5 stars was the cooling unit that’s included. I just can’t stand the plastic screws/pins that plant it into the motherboard. Made it next to impossible to install. I ended up just using my old one.Other than that, this thing rocks.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsI use a H100i to cool it and i get cooler temps than i did ...

I live in Florida and it gets hawt here, right now my temps are 27-31c but when i have my a/c on, the lowest ive seen it go for one core is about 23c but it'll range from 23-27c.Kinda wish i got the Intel Xeon Processor E3-1231V3B since its basically the same processor, down clocked a little bit and without an integrated processor. Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2017
Reviews: well i had an i5k that wasn't holding up to what my rebuild computer was meant to do which was video editing and gaming.so i went with a regular i7 thinking it would of ran great no problem...big mistake.it's been about a month and now the core is generating so much heat that the cases ambient temps and core temps are maxed out, won't cool down(and yes i am running equal amount in and equal amount out creating neutral pressure using brand new fans)what so ever and it's dangerous to run on maxed out temperatures especially risking damage to other vital parts of the pc let alone reverse the lovely soldering work done by the part manufactures.so since this fever mode started my build hasn't been able to run since the end of last month.the neutral pressure zone created by equality of fans and the evo 212 aren't keeping this hot head under control.and the room is constantly cold since room temps do make a difference and computers are like penguins they like the cold by default.but overall not worth it so the i5k will be returning to its original home.if you want an i7 save your money, reserve your computers well being for something better.to some it ain't much different but to others it does make a difference so since the i7k runs about 5 degrees cooler not oc just get that instead of this hot flashing nightmare.can't wait to get rid of it

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2016
Reviews: Although Dell recommended this as an upgrade for an i-3 4130 in an Alienware X51 R2, the fan and heatsink don't fit the 0PGRP5 mobo correctly.  The plastic push pins are very difficult to get engaged correctly.  They're also just long enough to prevent the heatsink from making good contact with the CPU, as evidenced by the poorly distributed thermal paste after uninstalling.  At start-up the temp hit 100°C and settled in the mid 70s at idle, and after running a game for a couple minutes the temp was up to 108°C, so the whole kit had to be removed.  The Dell fan/heatsink used screws, a much simpler solution than the pushpins, that probably would have prevented this issue.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-4790 Processor - BX80646I74790
Review Title: 3.0 out of 5 starsbad heat sink - nice processor

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThis CPU can handle the job at a cost effective price.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2012
Reviews: The I7-3770 is an optimal purchase for a cost-effective build that provides good performance and options for the foreseeable future. This CPU is fast, stable and when paired with a quality motherboard and 16gb of DDr-1600 RAM it multi-tasks and blows through applications as well as one can expect. You always can "do better" but only if you move up a series and/or go with twin CPUs and likewise and pay double. Use any money you save with this processor to buy yourself a step-up in motherboard, video card, memory, HDD/SSD, etc.:Points to Ponder:(A)If you like/want/need to overclock the INTEL "K" series processor are designed for that. That said, Intel may deny a return on any failed "K" series processor due to the possibility of end user foul-up.(B)Unless you are a the "Sheldon Cooper" type, the minor difference in native speed between the I7-3770 and I7-3770K is not noticeable for common tasks such as word processing, spreadsheets, databases, speech recognition, video playback and 3D games. With my system, video / audio / photo editing and production are optimal and I have yet to get a lockup when multitasking between as many as a dozen apps.(C)If 70% of your use and need is purely to "game" then go with any of the Intel I5 series. This I7 CPU is excellent for games but why spend the extra if you do not have the constant need for it? The CPU does count but gamers get the most bang for their bucks via a higher end video cards.(Heat issue fears with the IVY series)Overheating has only been a reported problem for those who overclock the "K" series and/or build and operate their systems poorly.Get a well vented case, good fans and CPU cooler, keep things clean of dust and hair and for God's sake don't operate in a 100+degree environment and you should be okay.(My build)I7-3770 CPUCorsair Hydro H60 CPU cooler (*Fan setup | interior-> (120mm push)->[HYDRO RADIATOR]->(120mm pull)-> exhaust from case)ASUS P8Z77-V Motherboard (*BIOS downloaded from ASUS and updated during 2nd test boot to fully support IVY bridge processor.)16GB G.SKILL Model F3-12800CL9D-8GBXL DDR-3 1600 RAM (*2 sets)SAMSUNG 830 series SSD as Primary Boot & Apps drive (*Firmware updated)Western Digital Black 1TB SATA III HDDXFX RADON HD 6870 1GB GPU video card (*using Microsoft Drivers)Rosewill HIVE 650 PSU. (*Modulator wires are just long enough in my build but extension are available.)Rosewill Challenger mid-tower case. (* several airflow case fan options to work with. It is a "decent tight fit" for ASUS P8Z77-V but, IMHO 1-inch longer footprint from front to back to allow more distance between the MB and drive cages would have been better.)

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsI am satisfied. Price was greatly reduced too but performance was ...
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2015
Reviews: I initially only wanted an entry level Intel Core i7 for our upgraded desktop since I found out that the technician, who custom-built our PC somewhat cheated us as to parts for a price of $1300 in early spring of 2011. This after I looked at the specs when I started noticing that our PC started hanging and rebooting for no reason while in use. So late last year I came up with a plan to upgrade it; after all, I was building my son's gaming PC so it would make no sense to me to build his with the latest specs while I watch my own custom PC wither away just because I trusted an a__hole to get it done for me. At that point last year I was no longer a computer "dinosaur'. I invested enough time reading gaming PC websites and had become confident that with proper timing, without compromising the latest specs as being outdated by the time I was done with my son's PC, to be able to make out my own version of custom gaming PC. This was how I stumbled in this product. Remember, I initially said that I only wanted an entry level Intel Core i7 processor in place of the lowly Intel Core i3 2100 that my cheating tech installed. Regardless of the replacement issues, I finally got to test it with the rest of the upgraded specs, using a 2011 motherboard which was forward compatible with what I have managed to scrap. Bam!!! Worked right away. I only need to flash the mobo so it would recognize this CPU. I have not even delved into the overclocking issues. Conclusion: this is not an entry level CPU. It is a lot more than that. It is capable of performing hyperthreading events and since I am an amateur DSLR photographer when we(my family) are on a road trip and do a lot of photo editing and recovery, it can do multitasking too without the hassle compared to the inferior Intel Core i3 2100s which deserves to go to a museum instead of an electronics store!!! 3 weeks into, I am satisfied. Price was greatly reduced too but performance was never comrpomised. Here are my final specs with this CPU at the core:1. Motherboard--GA P67A D3 B3 rev 1.0; 2. CPU--Intel Core i7 3770  3.4 GHz; 3. CPU heatsink--Coolermaster Hyper 212 EVO; 4. Memory(Dual Channel)--16 GB Crucial(8x2) DDR3 1333mHz and Kingston 8GB(4x2) DDR3 1333mHz, total of 24GB; 5. Graphics card: EVGA GTX GeForce 960 SSC 2GB; Power Supply--Antec HCG 750w 80 Plus Bronze with 135 mm fan with white LEDs(fully modular) 6.Drives--1 SSD Crucial M500 120 GB as boot drive and 2TB(1x2) WD 7200 RPM as storage drives and 7. Antec Case with 2 fans.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGreat Power but concerned about temperature
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2013
Reviews: Very powerful processor at a great price! I bought this product in part because I was afraid it would soon become unavailable due to the emergence of the new Haswell processors. I bought it shortly it went up in price from $274.99 to about $285. Shortly after I bought it, it went back down in price again to $274.99 (probably to match Newegg's promotion during that time period). I will try to see if I can get a refund in the price difference.Anyways, it runs great, but I am concerned that it runs a little to hot for normal use/idle. It is running anywhere between 40 to 45 degree celsius in my setup, which is concerning. I've read online that the Ivy Bridge processors run quite a bit more hotter than the previous generation and the current (Haswell) chips, so I'm keeping that in mind, in addition to the fact that I live in Hawaii where the climate is quite hot and muggy. I'd love to hear input from anyone here on if they think these temperatures are normal (I can't seem to find any forums about this chip and its temperatures, but plenty of information on the K version).I'm using the stock cooler on this chip, which btw, the instructions in the box simply shows you picture diagrams of how to install the chip and cooler, but no real tips and tricks, recommendations, etc., or any info at all, about the thermal paste that is already on the cooler, best practices, etc.I have this chip on a Gigabyte H77N-Wi-Fi board, inside a BitFenix Prodigy case (which is small, but not that small for an mini ITX case, but surprisingly has plenty of room for cable management) with a Corsair CX 600M modular power supply. I'm running the stock bit-fenix 120mm case fan for the rear cooler plugged straight into the motherboard. I replaced the front fan with a molex powered 120mm case fan by Thermaltake. I even added a third fan (another thermaltake) at the top right over the motherboard. However, after noticing it started running even hotter! (46 to 51 degree celsius), I did more research and now I've learned there are even more important things to consider such as fan direction, air pressure balance, etc. (I'm still quite new at building custom computers). Any input anyone has for me would go a long way and would be appreciated!Hopefully, I can start doing more testing on this rig to see if it is defective or not. I could probably live with the high mid 40 degrees celsius idle temps, even if this represents a defect, if my system stays under around 85 or 80 degrees Celsius at full load (running a game with a dedicated graphics card, etc.)Thanks!

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsBlown away by the speed, incredible multitasking
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2012
Reviews: I opted for this CPU since I use lots of virtual machines for my day-to-day programming tasks, so having hyper-threaded virtual cores is somewhat worthwhile. Since this is the non-K version I can't overclock but I do get extra features like VT-x that most users probably won't need, but help with virtualization.With 16GB of RAM, I can easily run multiple guest operating systems on top of Windows 8 and the whole system still just flies. Even with folding@home running simultaneously using all 8 cores, I still have great multitasking performance. The guest operating systems feel as though they were installed to the bare metal computer.I've read lots of complaints about the stock cooler but I think most of those are unfounded. At idle, the fan is barely audible. My idle temperatures are around 35-45*C. The fan does spin up at higher loads, but it's still not noisy. Running folding@home it gets up to about 80*C, which while hot is well within Intel's thermal specification. Plenty of GPUs routinely have higher load temperatures than this. Using the IntelBurnTest, I get up to about 90-95*C which while very toasty is still below the maximum allowable temperature, and still stable. In practice, few or no applications will generate as much heat as this test. So unless you're overclocking, which is disabled on this particular chip anyway, you're probably fine with the stock cooler.Overall, highly recommended. I can't believe how much faster this machine feels than my old C2D E8400 machine with 4GB of RAM, which was already quick to begin with.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsA very stable, fast and exceptional processor that runs great in a very tight itx htpc system.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2013
Reviews: I installed this in the intel dh77df itx motherboard for my htpc along with an Intel ssd drive and max (16gb) memory in an Antec ISK-110 case. Whew! this processor is so smooth and fast that it made my i5 processor seems to feel as if its going in reverse. My applications open really fast and the video playback is flawless. Previously I purchased one of the "K" series of these processors and was tweaking it by overclocking the processor. It was really, really fast but I didn't have any self control and kept trying to get more and more ghz from the "K" series processor until I tweaked it a bit too much and damaged the chip. This is why and how I decided to stick with this processor model instead. So if you really don't have any self control like me, better off getting this chip and save yourself a lot of heartache. The chip is fast, reliable and run very cool with the stock heatsink and fan unit it comes with. All this was running Win8 which I regret purchasing and should have stayed with Win7. However, this chip made Win8 really move even with all the little annoyances of the operating system.

Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSolid processor, fast and reliable
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2013
Reviews: This chip comes with a cooler that is ready to attach to latest Intel socket.  Very easy to install on the motherboard.  It's fast enough without overclocking.  If you want to overclock get the 3770K.  Still, the motherboard and the chip communicate to allow some tweaking but playing around with the settings is really unnecessary.  Combined with the OS on a solid state drive, this chip and a reliable MB make for the fastest computer I have ever owned, and I mean noticeably fast.  The OS boots up in seconds.  The aps and programs load almost instantly (unless the software slows load times purposefully to display startup and info screens).With this chip, a mid level graphics card and a good MB you can build a creditable gaming computer for well under $1000.00, that is pretty much future-proof; at least for the next ten years or so.  That's because most compatible motherboards will have USB 3.0, displayport outputs, SATA 6MB/s and other state of the art ports and connectors with upgradeable bios.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 3.0 out of 5 starsI think I got a used chip
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2022
Reviews: Chip did not come in original Intel packaging. It came in a brown box with none of the Intel literature. It also had scratch marks on the sides indicating it had been placed in a motherboard before. It says new but I suspect it's not.It was a whole ordeal getting it working on my part. Turns out I needed to update the bios for the chip to be recognized. Don't forget to do that if you're coming from a gen 2 like I did.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGreat CPU for the money, however.....
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2022
Reviews: The core, although 10+ years old, runs great. I put it into a Fedora Atomic rig that I use to serve up Docker containers. For this purpose, it's a beast. I can't speak to using it for gaming. I would suspect, if running older games it would be fine. (Although the CPU really isn't the main factor with gaming anymore; it's the GPU.) Here's my beef: I specifically ordered a NEW CPU versus a refurbished one, meaning I spent roughly $50 more for it. However, what came was not in a retail box with the holographic Intel stickers keeping the box closed to prove its contents are "genuine." It came in a plain brown cardboard box. The CPU itself was in a small heat sealed pouch, and the plastic clamshell it was in wouldn't close properly. Also, no documentation of any kind. Admittedly, the CPU works. But if I wanted something that could very well be refurbished, I would have saved myself the $50 and ordered a refurbished unit. I feel slightly cheated.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2013
Reviews: I just purchased the Intel i7-3770 (BX80637I73770) and the Fan was Dead on Arrival. I made sure I checked the connections from the fan to the mother board and also unwound the wires from the top of the fan as it looked like it may inhibit the fan from turning. The fan still didn't work. So I retested by turning back on the computer with the CPU fan plugged into one of the chase fan ports and confirmed it was a dead fan.I will update my review when I get a new fan from Intel and see if the CPU works.6/5/2014 update:As comp_junk mentioned, this was not a good review of the cpu itself but a problem with a part. I do agree, but I put the product with a 2 star rating because of frustration. I had all parts ready to go with dedicated time alloted, but the outcome was a nonfuntioning computer because of the sub par fan that comes with this CPU.I ended up getting an after market fan to replace the doa fan because one, there was "paper work" to fill out and warranty junk to process through and second, the time wasn't worth me getting another junk stock fan.So the review of the actual product... it is great. I have not had any problems with a lack of power what so ever. I have run 2 virtual machines running database queries and processing batch data all the while working and developing in visual studios. This cpu can handle it all no problem. I have upped my star review to a solid 4 only because of the fan problems.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsAmazing CPU for older builds
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2023
Reviews: I took a chance with the price on this CPU and from this vendor and happy to say it is a genuine Intel i7 3770 in new condition with fan. Very, very good purchase. Thank you. And as for the CPU performance..... Awesome! Very happy.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGreat CPU for old Dell XPS 8500
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
Reviews: I want to get a few more years out of my 7 year old dell Pc. This CPU is the fastest CPU that my dell pc supports. The seller's price was cheaper than what dell wanted for this CPU 7 years ago. The box and instructions were all in Chinese, but the engraving on the chip itself was in English with a made in Costa Rica Label.  Since this a dell pc I had to use the dell OEM fan and heatsink, not the supplied intel fan and heatsink. I used 91% alcohol to clean the dell heatsink, let dry, and then I used corsair thermal paste on the new CPU before screwing the dell heatsink in place, then I let the thermal paste cure for a while. finally I booted my pc into bios holding F12, the bios showed the new intel i7-3770 at 3.4 ghz. I saved the changes and then rebooted straight into windows with no errors or blue screens.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 4.0 out of 5 starsLet's not delude ourselves
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2012
Reviews: This is a great CPU, but let's not delude ourselves to justify a bad purchase or to mislead others.  There's little reason to buy this over the K model.  Very few virtual PC software out there can take advantage of the extra capabilities the non-K version has.  And the ones that can usually don't see much performance improvement.  The few that do are specialty software products for network administrators.  Unless you're one of them and you know for sure the virtual OS software you'll be using takes advantage of it and sees a performance boost, get the K.  Otherwise you'll just be kicking yourself for not paying ten bucks more to have overclocking ability.  Sure, the Ivy Bridge CPUs do not overclock like the prior generation, but the slight boost that is possible even on air will do far more than you're likely to get out of the non-K's bonus features... let alone spending ten bucks on some other part of the computer.  CPU speed affects nearly everything your computer does, so even a little bit extra helps.  Let's get real, folks, and call all these glowing five-star reviews what they are: trying to feel good about the wrong purchase.  Man up to it.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsIntel Processor, Exceeding Expectations
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2013
Reviews: I've only had the processor for less than a month, but I love how quick it is compared to the processor I upgraded from.  I had an AMD F1 board with a 3650 in it.  I also had (in crossfire) two AMD 6870s.  The graphics were great, but I always got little lag spikes.  Realizing I was bottle necking my performance with a budget processor, I decided to replace it with an Intel board, with a chip that is untouchable (according to benchmarks) from AMD.  I can't be happier with my decision.My AMD 3650 received a score of 8700 on 3D Mark Vantage Performance mode.  My Intel 3770 receives a 29715 score.  Same video cards and memory, slightly different hard drive setup, but nothing that should change that score.  Additionally, not sure if its the motherboard or the fact that the CPU can handle it more, but my graphics also went up from 22000 gpu score to 30711.  Could just be a limitation of the motherboard, but I like to think that the Intel CPU helped push that more.Glad I could purchase something for the long-term instead of dumping less into a short-term solution.  The i7 should last me 4-5 years at least for gaming.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThis is an original OEM processor in an unopened box.

Reviews: I installed this processor into my recently purchased "AMAZON RENEWED" HP desktop for the heck of it. It was surprising how much of an improvement it made in overall performance. Although this is an third generation I7 and will probably never be WIN 11 compatible, I will enjoy it until I can come up with a plan B.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsOnly had it a few days so far
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2012
Reviews: I have put this in an Asus Sabertooth Z77 mb, windows 8 performance page is reporting this processor at a score of 8.0.  I do not have it overclocked at all.I am playing alot of swtor atm, and i upgraded to this from an intel dual core 2 at 1.8ghz, also upgraded the mb and memory, same graphics card which is a galaxy brand Geforce GTX 460 758mb, directx shows the mem at 4051 mb, factory overclock.So with the same vid card though, I went from about 5-25fps in swtor at medium settings (sometimes down to 5 in combat or around a ton of ppl - 25 while on my personal ship with no one else around)  Maybe it would even go lower, I would litterally have to sometimes stop and just turn a little and wait over and over to get anywhere around alot of ppl.  not as bad in combat though.Now I am on max settings and running at 35-65 fps, I drop to 35 or so while i am in combat with a group of 8, and around 10 enimies, usually while running around solo questing I am sitting at around 55 fps.  such a huge improvement.  Also went from vista 32bit to 8  64 bit.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2013
Reviews: Just finished building my new tower. Not as cheap a proposition as it once was, but this way I have complete control as to what the computer has inside, plus it will fit my needs like a glove. Not to mention, I bought all my parts with quality and durability in mind.I could have gone with a Core i5, but given that Haswell just came out, this little processor has gone down in price. Not a lot, mind you, but enough to make it an attractive choice. So, I went for it. My new computer is only two days old. It is whisper quiet, and thanks to this processor and a decent video card, plenty fast as well. Thought for a while about getting the 3770K for a while, but ultimately decided it was not worth the price or the risk to eke out a bit more performance SAFELY (I am clearly not obsessed with overclocking). So, all in all, very satisfied with my purchase. I hope this Core i7 provides me with years of trouble free operation and fun.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2012
Reviews: I believe this is an excellent CPU. It runs with no problem. I have a couple of additional comments to make, especially concerning some comments in other reviews. By the way, I used this to replace an i7-920 (which also required a new motherboard because it uses a different socket).1. Although this CPU is supposedly not able to be overclocked (except for turbo mode), I find that is easily overclocked. My Asus P8Z11-V Deluxe motherboard (and its utilities) will automatically overclock it to about 4.22 G. It runs there 24 hours a day with no problems or instability. Of course, it won't overclock as much as the i7-1770K.2. Concerning using the Intel CPU cooler that came with it: I used that at the beginning because I needed to get a different backplate for my CoolerMaster V8 CPU cooler. It did work, but was hot. With the V8 installed it runs more than 15 C cooler (at full load,(running folding at home with SMP (using 6 or 8 cores) and 2 GPUs) than with the original Intel cooler. So, if you overclock it and run it hard, I would recommend getting an after-market CPU cooler even though it will run somewhat OK with the original Intel cooler.I highly recommend this processor.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsAmazing upgrade, at least from my old system
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2012
Reviews: I'm finally updating from my old Phenom II X4 940 AM2 box. It was loud, dusty, and crude, and just didn't have anywhere to go.First impression: this thing is FAST. Really, I don't do anything other than encoding that makes it break a sweat.Installed without problems on an ASRock Z77 Extreme4 with 16GB Patriot 2133MHz RAM. Had to bump RAM voltage to 1.56 for stability, even at stock speeds, but otherwise no tweaks. I'm using the low-end Antec Kuhler H2O 620 for the HSF in a Fractal Arc case. While the processor was basically normal price everything else was from some pre-BF sale. Moved my Intel SSD RAID0 and GTX 560 ti card from the AMD box.Wow. Clocking to 4.2GHz was ridiculously simple with the ASRock board. Memory bandwidth is over the top. CPU Passmark is just over 11K. Temps hit mid-80s C running IntelBurnTest. Swapped two Kingston HyperX 3K SSDs for the Intels - still RAID0 - and now diskmark is over 7300; ATTO says over 1GB/s for both 4K reads and writes.Coming from my old X4 system this is like night & day. Loving it.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsChose this over the 3770K
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2012
Reviews: I decided to go with this processor over the 3770K.  I previously owned the 2600K, but I never overclocked and didn't see a need to go with another K processor if I wasn't going to be overclocking the chip.  There is a lot of tweaking and testing involved in overclocking that I wasn't willing to research and spend hours on, and I'm pretty pleased with the speed as is.This chip does run a bit hotter than Sandy Bridge processors under load, and I noticed my fans run a bit higher, but you do gain access to PCI-E 3.0 and a some other features not available under Sandy Bridge.In my opinion, you don't really need to upgrade to Ivy Bridge unless you really want early access to PCI-E 3.0 or some other features.  The speed between my current system and the last are similar, but I enjoy knowing my system can use current and future PCI-E 3.0 devices to their full advantage.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2019
Reviews: One thing to know is the non-K version on many motherboard BIOS will have an overclock non-K option. You can't control it much as it just ups the boost but you can set this to boost to 4.3 Ghz which is pretty damn good. Play EVERY game I can on MAX everything with a 1070. Games that are CPU heavy though run smooth as I could ever want. For the age and the price it don't get much better unless you get the K version which I don't need to overclock as seems like you just might shorten life-span for a little reward. Beat the previous I5 2550 hands down. Glad I spent the money.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsGood processor with VT-D support
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2012
Reviews: If you need VT-D support for VMWare etc, be sure to get this instead of the i7-3770k. The K processor has a tiny bit higher base clock speed, and might be a bit cheaper. If you don't need the virtualization support get the K chip. I upgraded a Q6600 and Gigabyte 965P mb to this processor and a Gigabyte GA-Z77X-D3H rev 1.1 Z77 motherboard with 32gb of ram. Again, if you need virtualization support, both the MB and processor need to support it. I had to dig into the PDF manual of the D3H board to make sure it was supported before purchasing. Overall, it is much faster than my Q6600 was. Lightroom renders 36mp D800 previews about 2x as fast. VM's are also now blazingly fast.As a side note, I was amazed I could pick up 32gb of ram for $105... If I ever need 3 VM's running while I work on something else, I'm sure this rig could handle it.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Title: 5.0 out of 5 starsWell worth the price!
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2012
Reviews: My first review with my first Intel processor. All I can say its stable, fast,and faster then my AMD Phenom II 965! Both are rated at 3.4mhz but this 3rd generation processor is 3 times faster in benchmarks and noticably faster in FPS games. I'm running it on the Asus Z77 Sabertooth board and in a few months I will be dropping out the pair of GTX-470's I have running in SLI, to be replaced with one GTX-670 or GTX-680 in the fall. My only problem with Intel is, its so dam expensive than a system with AMD. WHY??? Yes they are fast, reliable chips, but so is AMD! Just not as fast. It all comes down to this, I wanted a CPU that will take me up into a build that was close to the top for a Gaming System, the i7 3770 or 3770K does it!I believe the 1155 platform will be around for sometime so check it out.

Product Title: Intel Core i7-3770 Quad-Core Processor 3.4 GHz 4 Core LGA 1155 - BX80637I73770
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2013
Reviews: This processor is more than I probably need, but it has served all my purposes well (primarily gaming).  Multi-tasks very well.  It's not uncommon for my rig to be running 2 or 3 virtual machines, while playing BF4 on High/Ultra settings.  My bottleneck at this point is GPU related, not CPU.  Previous processor was a Sandy Bridge i5, and this runs a bit warmer, but nothing to be concerned about it, especially when paired with a CoolerMaster Hyper 212.  There's not much difference between the i5 and the i7 in day to day usage, and it's true, most would be just fine with sticking with the i5.  I don't regret the change, but if you're budget is tight I would recommend spending the extra on a better GPU rather than bumping up to the i7...unless you plan to stream your playing to the internet.
